head.title: Duality between Lagrangian and Legendrian invariants
head.abstract:
Consider a pair , of a Weinstein manifold with an exact Lagrangian submanifold , with ideal contact boundary , where is a contact manifold and is a Legendrian submanifold. We introduce the Chekanov-Eliashberg DG-algebra, , with coefficients in chains of the based loop space of and study its relation to the Floer cohomology of . Using the augmentation induced by , can be expressed as the Adams cobar construction applied to a Legendrian coalgebra, . We define a twisting cochain: via holomorphic curve counts, where denotes the bar construction and the graded linear dual. We show under simply-connectedness assumptions that the corresponding Koszul complex is acyclic which then implies that and are Koszul dual. In particular, induces a quasi-isomorphism between and the cobar of the Floer homology of , .
This generalizes the classical Koszul duality result between and for a simply-connected manifold, where is the based loop space of , and provides the natural geometric ingredient explaining the computations given in in the case when is a plumbing of cotangent bundles of 2-spheres (where an additional weight grading ensured Koszulity of ).
We use the duality result to show that under certain connectivity and locally finiteness assumptions, is quasi-isomorphic to for any Lagrangian filling of .
Our constructions have interpretations in terms of wrapped Floer cohomology after versions of Lagrangian handle attachments. In particular, we outline a proof that is quasi-isomorphic to the wrapped Floer cohomology of a fiber disk in the Weinstein domain obtained by attaching to along (or, in the terminology of the wrapped Floer cohomology of in with wrapping stopped by ).

outline._note: In this introduction we first give an overview of our results. The overview starts with a review of well known counterparts of our constructions in algebraic topology. We then introduce our Legendrian and Lagrangian invariants in Sections and , respectively, and discuss the connection between them and applications thereof in Section . Finally, in Section we give detailed calculations of the invariants introduced in the simple yet illustrative example of the Legendrian Hopf link filled by two Lagrangian disks intersecting transversely in one point. The starting point for our study is a construction in classical topology. Consider the following augmented DG-algebras over a field associated to a based, connected, topological space : where is the singular cochain complex equipped with the cup-product and is the singular chain complex of the based loop space of equipped with the Pontryagin product. (We use cohomologically graded complexes throughout the paper so that all differentials increase the grading by 1.) In the case of singular cohomology, the inclusion gives the augmentation and in the case of the based loop space, the augmentation is given by the trivial local system . If is of finite-type (for example, a finite CW-complex), then it is well known that one can recover the augmented DG-algebra from the augmented DG-algebra by the Eilenberg-Moore equivalence: In the other direction, if is SIMPLY CONNECTED, then the Adams construction gives a quasi-isomorphism and in this case and are said to be KOSZUL DUAL DG-algebras. Koszul duality is sometimes abbreviated and simply called DUALITY. For more general , using the method of acyclic models, Brown constructed a twisting cochain This is a degree 1 map that induces a DG-algebra map . By definition, the latter is a quasi-isomorphism when duality holds, and this can be detected by an associated KOSZUL COMPLEX, which is acyclic if and only if duality holds. In the general case, is a certain completion of and consequently is a more refined invariant of than . In this paper, we pursue this idea in the context of invariants associated to Lagrangian and Legendrian submanifolds. Here the role played by simple connectivity in the above discussion have two natural counterparts, one corresponds to a generalized notion of simply-connectedness for intersecting Lagrangian submanifolds and the other is the usual notion of simply-connectedness for Legendrian submanifolds. We start with the geometric data of a Liouville domain with convex boundary and an exact Lagrangian submanifold with Legendrian boundary . We assume that , that the Maslov class of vanishes (for grading purposes) and that is relatively spin (to orient certain moduli spaces of holomorphic disks). Assume that is subdivided into embedded components intersecting transversely and that is subdivided into connected components . To avoid notational complications, we take both parametrized by the same finite set and assume that the boundary of is . We use a base field and define the semi-simple ring generated by mutually orthogonal idempotents . Also, we fix a partition into two disjoint sets, and choose a base-point for each . For simplicity, let us restrict, in this introduction, to the following situation: is a subcritical Liouville domain, If then the corresponding Legendrian is an embedded SPHERE. From a technical point of view, these restrictions are unnecessary. We make them in order to facilitate the explanation of the meaning of our constructions for Legendrian surgery. (Note that, the topology of is unrestricted when .) We write for the completion of the Liouville “sector” obtained from by attaching critical Weinstein handles along for each and cotangent cones along for each . If , is an ordinary Liouville manifold. In general, it looks like a neighborhood of the zero section in the cotangent bundle , for some , outside a compact subset. Hence it is a geometrically bounded manifold, Gromov compactness holds , and holomorphic curve theory is well-behaved. In , for , there is a closed exact Lagrangian submanifold , the union of the Lagrangian in and the LAGRANGIAN CORE DISK of the Weinstein handle attached to , and for , there is a non-compact Lagrangian obtained by attaching the cylindrical boundary to for , which we will still denote by , by abuse of notation, even when we view them now in . Dually, for each , we obtain (non-compact) exact Lagrangian disks , the LAGRANGIAN COCORE DISKS of the Weinstein handles attached to on , and for each , we construct DUAL Lagrangians disks intersecting once and asymptotic to a Legendrian meridian of (these can be constructed as the cotangent fiber at the point , , in , where is the base points on ). The invariants that we will construct are associated to the union of Lagrangian submanifolds The Lagrangian will be referred to as a LAGRANGIAN SKELETON of , it is a union of Lagrangian submanifolds which intersect transversely. The dual Lagrangian is the union of Lagrangian disks which can be locally identified with cotangent fibers to irreducible components of . We will study two algebraic invariants associated to . The first one is the LEGENDRIAN -ALGEBRA, . It corresponds to the endomorphism algebra of considered in the infinitesimal Fukaya category of . The second one is the CHEKANOV-ELIASHBERG DG-ALGEBRA, . It corresponds to the endomorphism algebra of considered in the partially wrapped Fukaya category of . However, we will take the pre-surgery perspective as in and construct all these invariants by studying Legendrian invariants of rather than Floer cohomology in . From this perspective, the case is a new construction, that generalizes the theory from in a way analogous to how partially wrapped Fukaya categories generalizes wrapped Fukaya categories . The invariants and come equipped with canonical augmentations to the semi-simple ring and it is easy to see by construction that is determined by via the equivalence: The duality which would recover from holds in the “simply-connected” case (see Section ). In the topological case discussed above, this is analogous to the simply-connectedness assumption on , which makes the augmented algebras and Koszul dual. In fact, the topological case is a special case of our study for the Weinstein manifold , with the Lagrangian skeleton given by the 0-section, and the dual Lagrangian given by a cotangent fiber . We next sketch the definition of our version of the Chekanov-Eliashberg DG-algebra (without any assumption of simply-connectedness). This is the DG-algebra over called above. Its underlying -bimodule is the unital -algebra freely generated by Reeb chords between components of and chains in for . (This is the crucial distinctions between and .) We use the cubical chain complex (cf. ) for , see Section for a discussion of other possible choices of chain models, to express as a free algebra over generated by Reeb chords and generators of for . Since is a free algebra over , the differential is determined by its action on generators. On a generator of we simply apply the usual differential. On a generator which is a Reeb chord, the differential is determined by moduli spaces of holomorphic disks in the symplectization which asymptotically converge to on the positive end and chords at the negative end as follows. (2,3) to (-0.5,0); (0,0) to (0.5,0); (1,0) to (1.5,0); (2,0) to (2.5,0); (3,0) to (3.5,0); (4,0) to (4.5,0); (2.5,3) to (5,0); (0,0) to (-0.5,0); (1,0) to (0.5,0); (2,0) to (1.5,0); (3,0) to (2.5,0); (4,0) to (3.5,0); (5,0) to (4.5,0); (2.5,3) to (2,3); at (2.3, 3.3) ; at (-0.25,-0.3) ; at (0.75,-0.3) ; at (1.75,-0.3) ; at (2.75,-0.3) ; at (3.75,-0.3) ; at (4.75,-0.3) ; at (1,2) ; at (0.25, 0.3) ; at (2.25, 0.3) ; at (3.25, 0.3) ; Consider the moduli space of -holomorphic maps , where is a disk with boundary punctures that are mutually distinct and respects the counter-clockwise cyclic order of , and sends the boundary component of to , and is asymptotic to near the puncture at for and to near the puncture at . The moduli space, which is naturally a stratified space with manifold strata that carries a fundamental chain, comes with evaluation maps to for . The image of the fundamental chain determines a word in our chain model of . Reading these together with the Reeb chords in order gives the differential of . We remark that loop space coefficients were used in the context of Lagrangian Floer cohomology before . See also , for uses of high-dimensional moduli spaces in Floer theory. While with loop space coefficients is a powerful invariant, it is in general hard to compute as it involves high-dimensional moduli spaces of disks. As mentioned above, duality in the Legendrian will also play a role. More precisely, we define another DG-algebra related to via a Morse theoretic version of Adams cobar construction whose definition involves taking parallel copies of but uses only 0-dimensional moduli spaces (see Section ). In fact, we prove that the two DG-algebras are quasi-isomorphic when for are simply-connected. There exists a DG-algebra map which is a quasi-isomorphism when is simply-connected for all .

outline.text: Partially wrapped Fukaya categories by surgery
outline._note: Let be a Legendrian submanifold and as above. Furthermore, we use the notation above for co-core disks and write . An important result that is implicit in is the following: Suppose , then there exists a surgery map defined via a holomorphic disk count that gives an quasi-isomorphism between the wrapped Floer cochain complex and the Legendrian DG-algebra . A complete proof of this result has not yet appeared in the literature. See Appendix for a discussion and a proof sketch. In Appendix , one can also find a construction of wrapped Floer algebra which uses only purely holomorphic disks, and a proof that this agrees with the more standard version defined in which uses Hamiltonian perturbations. One of the main guiding principles for the results in this paper is that Theorem remains true when is non-empty, provided the Lagrangians are considered as objects of the PARTIALLY WRAPPED Fukaya category of , where the non-capped Legendrians for serve as STOPS (cf. ). The full proof of this result when is non-empty will appear elsewhere. We give an outline in Appendix . Here we will use the geometric intuition provided by this viewpoint and our constructions of Legendrian invariants provide a rigorous “working definition” of even in the case that is non-empty, and also a starting point for the study of “partially wrapped Fukaya categories” via Legendrian surgery (extending the scope of considerably). For future reference, we state this result as a conjecture: There exists a surgery map defined via moduli spaces of holomorphic disks which gives an quasi-isomorphism between the partially wrapped Floer cochain complex and the DG-algebra . While writing this paper, we learned that Z. Sylvan independently considered a similar conjecture in relation with his theory of partially wrapped Fukaya categories .

We keep the notation above and now consider an exact Lagrangian filling in of . Such a filling gives an augmentation For chords on components , this is well known and given by a count of rigid disks with one positive puncture and boundary on . For chords on components , the same count composed with the augmentation on corresponding to the trivial local system gives the augmentation. This allows us to write for an coalgebra that we call the LEGENDRIAN -COALGEBRA (which depends on ). Here is the Adams cobar construction. Writing for the algebra which is the linear dual of , the following result recovers the Floer cochain complex of in . There exists an quasi-isomorphism between the Floer cochain complex in the infinitesimal Fukaya category of , and the -module homomorphism of the -module , . Note that, by the general properties of bar-cobar constructions (see Section ), the algebra is quasi-isomorphic to the graded -dual of the bar construction on the algebra , which can be computed as Let us remark that in the case is empty, the algebra is obtained from the construction in and , known as category, by adding a copy of making it unital. On the other hand, in the case is empty, the algebra is related to the category of . In the setting of microlocal sheaves, a related result was obtained by Nadler .

outline.text: Duality between partially wrapped and infinitesimal Fukaya categories
outline._note: We study duality in the setting of the two categories described above: the partially wrapped Fukaya category and the infinitesimal Fukaya category of (after surgery), or equivalently, the augmented DG-algebra and the augmented algebra (before surgery). As we have seen in Theorem , the augmented DG-algebra determines the augmented (unital) algebra . Now, a natural question is to what extent the quasi-isomorphism type of the algebra determines the quasi-isomorphism type of the augmented Legendrian DG-algebra . We emphasize here the phrase “quasi-isomorphism type”: even though it is possible to construct chain models of the algebra (which is quasi-isomorphic to ) and the DG-algebra by counting “the same” holomorphic disks interpreted in different ways, the two algebras are considered with respect to different equivalence relations, and the resulting equivalence classes can be very different. In particular, it is NOT generally true that being a quasi-isomorphism of -coalgebras implies that is a quasi-isomorphism. We will study this question by (geometrically) constructing a TWISTING COCHAIN (see Section ): where stands for the bar construction and is the graded -dual. This twisting cochain induces a map of DG-algebras: which is a quasi-isomorphism if and only if is a KOSZUL twisting cochain. For example, we will prove the following result. Suppose that is a locally finite, simply-connected -bimodule, then the natural map is a quasi-isomorphism. This is an instance of KOSZUL DUALITY between the algebras and . This duality has many useful implications. For example, it implies an isomorphism between Hochschild cohomologies: When , an isomorphism defined via a surgery map was described between SYMPLECTIC COHOMOLOGY, , and the Hochschild cohomology . Therefore, when duality holds, we obtain a more economical way of computing . In the case of cotangent bundles of simply-connected manifolds , this recovers a classical result due to Jones , which gives: where is simply-connected manifold of dimension and denotes the free loop space of . In Section , we give several concrete examples where the duality holds beyond the case of cotangent bundles. For example, the duality holds for plumbings of simply-connected cotangent bundles according to an arbitrary plumbing tree, see Theorem . In another direction, combining duality and Floer cohomology with local coefficients, we establish the following result for relatively spin exact Lagrangian fillings with vanishing Maslov class of a Legendrian submanifold . Let and assume that and that is simply-connected. If is supported in degrees , then is simply connected. Moreover, if is a sphere then is isomorphic to , where , for a disk with boundary . In general, duality between and does not hold (as can be seen for example by looking at cotangent bundles of non-simply connected manifolds or, letting be the standard Legendrian trefoil knot in filled by a punctured torus). However, there are cases when duality holds even if is not simply-connected, for instance because of the existence of an auxiliary weight grading, see or for an example in the 1-dimensional case see . It is a very interesting open question to find a geometric characterization of when duality holds. As is well known, general constructions of Legendrian and Lagrangian holomorphic curve invariants require the use of so-called abstract perturbations. For our main invariant , all moduli spaces used can be shown to be transverse by classical techniques (see Theorem ( )) except for the rigid holomorphic planes in with a single positive end that are used to anchor the disks in the terminology of . (These are also relevant for defining the wrapped Floer cochain complex without Hamiltonian perturbations and for constructing the surgery map). In symplectic field theory similar transversality problems are dealt with by appealing to virtual perturbation techniques, see e.g. . Here we will not work out the details of this but merely assume such a perturbation scheme has been fixed. Our results are independent of the particular choice. We also point out that our construction of applies without reference to virtual techniques in a number of interesting cases where splitting off of holomorphic planes can be ruled out for topological reasons. For example, if there are no contractible Reeb orbits, e.g. for .

In this section, we study the example of the Hopf link in order to illustrate our results in a simple and computable example. Some of the algebraic constructions used here are explained in detail only later, see Section . For degree reasons, the only possible non-trivial higher products are: It turns out that one can take for all . This is the free coalgebra with and and the only non-trivial differential not involving counits is We have a twisting cochain given by This means that satisfies the following equations: Hence, it induces a DG-algebra map We have not checked whether this is a quasi-isomorphism, or equivalently whether is a KOSZUL twisting cochain. In this section, we review the homological algebra we use in our study of various invariants associated to Legendrian submanifolds and their Lagrangian fillings. Most of this material is well established, see and also , , , , . Note though that our sign conventions follow , see Remark .

In this section we will discuss the basic algebraic objects we use. These are modules over a ground ring of the following form. Fix a coefficient field (of arbitrary characteristic) and let be a semi-simple ring of the form: where and for , and where the index set is finite. We will use -graded -bimodules. If is such a module then we call CONNECTED if and either for all , or for all , and we call SIMPLY-CONNECTED if, in addition, in the former case and in the latter . Further, we say that is LOCALLY FINITE if each is finitely generated as a -bimodule. We have the usual shifting and tensor product operations on modules. If is a graded -bimodule and is an integer then we let the corresponding shifted module be the module with graded components If is another graded -bimodule then is naturally a graded -bimodule with For iterated tensor products we write Our modules will often have further structure as -graded -algebras and -coalgebras over , see Sections and . The modules are then in particular chain complexes with a differential and we will use COHOMOLOGICAL grading throughout. That is, the differential INCREASES the grading by 1. For example, if is a topological space then its cohomology complex is supported in non-negative grading, while the homology complex is supported in non-positive degrees. To be consistent with this, we denote the grading as a subscript (resp. superscript) when the underlying chain complex has a coalgebra (resp. algebra) structure.

An -ALGEBRA over is a -graded -module with a collection of grading preserving -linear maps for all integers , that satisfies the -relations: for all . We follow the sign conventions of . Note that even though, is written on the left of , the sign convention is so that acts from the right. To be consistent, we will insist that all our operators act on the right independently of how they are written. This convention and the usual Koszul sign exchange rule determine the signs that appear in our formulas. A DG-ALGEBRA over is an -algebra such that for . In this case, we call the first two operations the DIFFERENTIAL and the PRODUCT, respectively, and use the following adjustments to obtain an (ordinary) differential graded algebra: In particular, the product is then associative and the graded Leibniz rule for holds: An -MAP between -algebras and over , with operations and , , respectively, is a collection of -linear grading preserving maps , that satisfies the relations An -map is called an -QUASI ISOMORPHISM if the map on cohomology induced by is an isomorphism. We say that an -algebra is STRICTLY UNITAL if there is an element such that , for any , and such that , annihilates any monomial containing as a factor. An AUGMENTATION of a strictly unital -algebra is an -map , where is considered as a strictly unital -algebra in degree 0 with trivial differential and higher -products, and such that , for annihilates any monomial containing . An augmentation is called if for . The category of augmented, strictly unital algebras is equivalent to the category of strictly augmented, strictly unital algebras (see ).

An -COALGEBRA over is a -graded -module with a collection of -linear grading preserving maps: for all integers , with the following properties. The maps satisfy the co--relations: where, Furthermore, the degree 1 map with component equal to , factorizes through the natural inclusion of the direct sum into the direct product. A DG-COALGEBRA over is an -coalgebra such that for . In this case, we call the first two operations the DIFFERENTIAL and the COPRODUCT, respectively, and use the following adjustments to obtain an (ordinary) differential graded coalgebra: where we write . In particular, the coproduct is coassociative (i.e. ) and the graded co-Leibniz rule holds: A DG-coalgebra is called CONILPOTENT (also called COCOMPLETE) if for any , there exists an such that is in the kernel of the iterated comultiplication map defined recursively by and , for . An -COMAP between -coalgebras and over , with operations and , , respectively, is a collection of -linear grading preserving maps , that satisfies the relations: where, Furthermore, the degree 0 map with component equal to , factorizes through the natural inclusion: of the direct sum into the direct product. An -comap is called an -QUASI ISOMORPHISM if the map on cohomology induced by is an isomorphism. We say that an -coalgebra is STRICTLY COUNITAL if there exists a -linear map such that and for all and . A COAUGMENTATION of a strictly counital -coalgebra is an -comap , where is considered as a vector space in degree 0 with the trivial -coalgebra structure, such that and for all and . The coaugmentation is called STRICT if for .

We next discuss the graded dual of a graded -module. Since we are working over a noncommutative ring , there are two -linear duals (cf. ). If is a graded -module, , then the and are defined as follows. The graded components of are left -module maps: and the -bimodule structure on is given as follows: if , , and , then The graded components of in degree are right -module maps, which we write as: and the -bimodule structure is given by: if , , and , then Both canonical maps and are -bimodule maps, which are isomorphisms if is locally finite. If are -bimodules, there is a natural map given by: Similarly, there is a natural map given by: These give the graded duals and of a coaugmented -coalgebra the structure of augmented -algebras with structure maps defined by: Note that to get a non-zero product, we must have , hence the sign equals the sign . In general, there is no natural way of equipping the graded dual of an augmented -algebra with an -coalgebra structure. However, if the grading on is locally finite (i.e. are finitely generated as -bimodules), then it follows that Therefore, the graded duals and of an augmented -algebra with locally finite grading are naturally coaugmented -coalgebras.

Let be an -coalgebra and let be a DG-algebra. A TWISTING COCHAIN is a -linear map of degree 1 that satisfies: where , and . Note that for , for only finitely many , and hence the potentially infinite sum in is actually finite when it acts on . If the coalgebra is coaugmented by and the algebra is augmented , we require in addition that its twisting cochains are compatible in the sense that We denote the set of twisting cochains from to by . Let be a twisting cochain. Consider the twisted tensor product as a chain complex with differential defined as follows, Here the differential squares to zero, , since satisfies . This complex is the KOSZUL COMPLEX associated with . It is called acyclic if the projection to is a quasi-isomorphism. Note that one also has an analogous complex of the form . The -vector space of -bimodule morphisms carries an -algebra structure with operations , given by and where the composition is defined component-wise. Thus, if , then where . In this setting, a twisting cochain corresponds to a solution of the Maurer-Cartan equation: (As before, this sum is effectively finite since for any , only for finitely many .). In particular, a twisting cochain defines a twisted -structure on , with operations given by We will denote this twisted -structure . There are direct analogs of the above construction if we instead consider a DG-coalgebra and an -algebra with operations . The module has the structure of an -algebra with operations given by: and To make sense of the twisting cochain equation , one needs to make additional assumptions to ensure the convergence of the infinite sum. This holds, for example, if is conilpotent. We remark that if both and are -(co)algebras, then defining a twisting cochain is a more complicated matter (cf. ). We will not need this here.
In this section we first introduce the bar and cobar constructions and then discuss basic relations between them.

Let be a strictly unital -algebra with a strict augmentation . Define the AUGMENTATION IDEAL . Note that if we are given a non-unital -algebra , then we can turn it into a strictly unital algebra with an augmentation given by projection to . We next recall the construction of the (reduced) BAR CONSTRUCTION . For any augmented -algebra , is a coaugmented conilpotent DG-coalgebra. As a coaugmented coalgebra is defined as where denotes the downwards shift by 1. We write a typical monomial using Eilenberg and Maclane’s notation: where for , denotes the corresponding element in with degree shifted down by 1. The differential is defined to vanish on , , and as follows on monomials: where strictness of the augmentation ensures that for . (If the augmentation is not strict, one applies a quasi-isomorphism of to make it strict.) The coproduct is defined by The slightly unusual sign appears as a consequence of the following two facts: The equation is equivalent to the -relations for , The pair satisfies the co- relations . Redefining to using removes the sign in , and becomes a (usual) coassociative DG-coalgebra, where the co-Leibniz rule holds. The coaugmentation is defined by letting be the inclusion of and for . There is an increasing, exhaustive, and bounded below (hence, complete Hausdorff) filtration on the complex : where This induces the WORD-LENGTH SPECTRAL SEQUENCE with converging strongly to by the classical convergence theorem (). It can be proved using this spectral sequence that an map is a quasi-isomorphism if and only if the naturally induced DG-coalgebra map is a quasi-isomorphism, see . There is a universal twisting cochain which is non-zero only on and is given by the inclusion map . The twisting cochain gives rise to a free -bimodule resolution of obtained as a twisted tensor product with the differential given by the following formula: This can be used to compute Hochschild homology and cohomology of with coefficients in an -bimodule . Consider instead a strictly counital -coalgebra with operations and with a strict coaugmentation . Let be the coaugmentation ideal. We next recall the COBAR CONSTRUCTION which associates a DG-algebra to . As an augmented algebra is: As before, we write a typical monomial as where for , denotes the corresponding element in with degree shifted up by 1. The differential on vanishes on , , and acts as follows on monomials: Here, by abuse of notation, we write for the induced coproduct . The product is given by: The slightly unusual sign appears as a consequence of the following two facts: The equation is equivalent to co- relations for . The pair satisfies the relations . Redefining to using removes the sign in , and becomes a (usual) associative DG-algebra, where Leibniz rule holds. The augmentation is given by letting to be the projection to and for . There is a decreasing, exhaustive, bounded above filtration on the complex : given by This gives the WORD LENGTH SPECTRAL SEQUENCE with Unlike the case of the word length filtration on the bar construction, for the cobar construction, in general, convergence may fail. Thus, we introduce completions. We define the COMPLETED COBAR CONSTRUCTION to be: The length filtration on induces a filtration on defined by: which is decreasing, exhaustive, bounded above and complete Hausdorff. The spectral sequence associated to the filtration on is isomorphic to the length spectral sequence associated with the filtration on and converges conditionally to (see ). It converges strongly to if the spectral sequence is regular, i.e., only finitely many of the differentials are nonzero for each and (see ). This holds, for example, if is locally finite. We say that is complete if the natural map is a quasi-isomorphism. For example, it is easy to see that this is the case if is locally finite and simply-connected. If is an -comap which is a quasi-isomorphism of -coalgebras and if is complete then is a quasi-isomorphism. (This follows from , see also ). The condition that is complete is necessary and is related to the completeness of the word length filtration. A counter-example when the completeness assumption is dropped can be found in . There is a universal twisting cochain given by the composition of canonical projection and the canonical inclusion .

Suppose that is a coaugmented -coalgebra and is an augmented DG-algebra, then we have a canonical bijection given by . Similarly, if is a coaugmented conilpotent DG-coalgebra and is an augmented -algebra, then we have a canonical bijection given by (see Lemme 3.17 ). Therefore, when is a coaugmented conilpotent DG-coalgebra, and is an augmented DG-algebra, we have the bar-cobar adjunction: Notice, in particular, that the natural DG-maps are quasi-isomorphisms for any DG-algebra and conilpotent DG-coalgebra (see ). It is also true that for any -algebra , the algebra map given by the adjunction map is an -quasi-isomorphism (see ). Note that any -quasi-isomorphism is invertible up to homotopy (). Similarly, for any -coalgebra , the -comap given by the adjunction map is an quasi-isomorphism. However, an quasi-isomorphism for a general -coalgebra is not usually a convenient notion, since as we remarked above a quasi-isomorphism of coalgebras between and does not necessarily induce a quasi-isomorphism of DG-algebras and . For this reason, one considers the category of CONILPOTENT coalgebras. Let be a coaugmented -coalgebra generated over by variables with some countable index set, such that there exists a total ordering where is a bijection. This produces an increasing filtration by setting . Suppose that the structure maps are compatible with this filtration, in the sense that, for all and . Then we call a conilpotent coalgebra. (More generally, a homotopy retract of such coalgebras are called conilpotent, cf. . This notion is called FINITE TYPE in .). Given two such coalgebras and , one considers filtered -comaps between them. In the case of a conilpotent DG-coalgebra there exists an increasing filtration on given by the subalgebras that plays the same role (see ). We next state the following elementary lemma for later convenience. Let be an augmented -algebra, such that the -bimodule structure on and are locally finite, then there are quasi-isomorphisms of augmented DG-algebras: Note that the assumption is satisfied when is simply-connected. We shall also consider the case when is assumed to be connected, then we have: Let be a connected, locally finite -bimodule equipped with an augmented -algebra structure, then there are maps of DG-algebras which become quasi-isomorphisms after completion:

Suppose is a coaugmented conilpotent -coalgebra and is an augmented DG-algebra, via the bijection , any twisting cochain is of the form for some unique . Similarly, if is a coaugmented DG-algebra and is an augmented -algebra, any twisting cochain is of the form for some . In either case above we call a KOSZUL TWISTING COCHAIN if is a quasi-isomorphism, and we denote the set of Koszul twisting cochains by . The terminology of Koszul twisting cochains is taken from . They are also called in other sources (cf. , ). This terminology is due to the well known fact that, under various locally finiteness assumptions, a twisting cochain is Koszul if and only if the Koszul complex ( ) associated is acyclic (cf. ). Informally, if then, depending on whether we write or , either can be used in place of or can be used in place of in various resolutions. This, in turn, may lead to smaller complexes to compute with. For example, one can compute Hochschild homology and cohomology of and using the -bimodule resolution of given by the complex: with the differential as in , see . Suppose that is an -algebra with an augmentation . The augmentation makes into a left -module or equivalently a right -module. The KOSZUL DUAL of an augmented -algebra is the DG-algebra of left -module maps from to itself: (Here, the -bimodule structure on is given by since is viewed as a left -module induced from its structure as a left -module. If instead, we have an augmentation of , then we view as a right -module, and the -bimodule structure on would be given by ). Recall that for a unital -algebra over a field (or a semisimple ring such as ) any -module is both -projective and -injective, that is, if is an -module over and is an acyclic module over , then the complexes and are acyclic . Hence, the DG-algebra can be computed as the -module homomorphisms from to itself. (More generally, this holds if is -projective as a complex of - modules, which implies that is -projective as an -module over .) Therefore, we have the following. If (resp. ) is an augmented unital -algebra then Recall that is quasi-isomorphic to as an - module. Hence, by the hom-tensor adjunction, we have . Since is -projective as a complex of -modules, so is , hence the latter is computed by . The cohomology is a graded algebra: Dually, we also have the derived tensor product , which can be computed by the complex . The cohomology is a graded coalgebra: In particular, note that if is a field, we have that by the universal coefficient theorem. If is a [**commutative**]{} algebra (or more generally an -algebra), then also has a graded algebra structure defined via: induced by the algebra map (which exists since is commutative). This should not be confused with the natural coalgebra structure above. Note that itself can be viewed as a left -module and the map is a map of left -modules, hence it induces a map of DG- algebras: which can in turn be viewed as an augmentation of since can again be identified with as it is the Yoneda image of as an -module. Hence, can be viewed as a right -module. The double-dual of is defined to be . There is a natural map from to its double-dual: defined via viewing the right -module as and acting on the left by . We say that and are Koszul dual if is a quasi-isomorphism. One standard situation when Koszul duality holds is the following: Suppose is a locally finite, simply-connected -bimodule equipped with an -coalgebra structure and the coaugmentation . Let , which is an augmented connected DG-algebra. Then and and are Koszul dual. In other words, the natural morphism is a quasi-isomorphism. First, observe that indeed by . Next, we have that where we applied Lemma to and used the fact that since is locally finite. In the case that is a locally finite, connected (but not simply-connected) -bimodule, Lemma no longer applies. We instead use Lemma to deduce the following weaker duality result. Let be a connected, locally finite -bimodule, equipped with an coalgebra structure and coaugmentation , and , which is an augmented DG-algebra where augmentation is given by projection to . Then and there is a quasi-isomorphism Note that in Proposition , is not connected, and may admit other augmentations than that induced by the cobar construction. Such augmentations will be considered below. For example, suppose that is a coaugmented coalgebra such that is generated by elements from an indexing set and that is an augmentation, which is induced by a map since is free. Now we can consider the coaugmented coalgebra such that Then and are quasi-isomorphic as non-augmented DG-algebras, and the augmentation on induced by the cobar construction coincides with the given augmentation on . When is not simply-connected, the proof of duality fails precisely because is not locally finite. Nevertheless, the duality result can still be proved in certain cases where an extra WEIGHT grading (internal degree, or Adams degree) is available (see , , ). We will not study this situation systematically in this paper, but it is important as it extends the range of applicability of Koszul duality theory. In the setting of Chekanov-Eliashberg DG-algebras, such a situation was considered in .

In this section we introduce our Legendrian invariants. We start with discussing a model for loop space coefficients in Section . In Section we define the Chekanov-Eliashberg algebra with loop space coefficients using moduli spaces of disks of all dimensions, and in Section we give a more computable version which uses only rigid disks and which carries the same information if the Legendrian submanifold is simply connected.

Before defining our Legendrian invariants, we describe chain models for their coefficients for . (Notation is as above, is a decorated connected component of the Legendrian .) We work over a field . Let denote the topological monoid of Moore loops based at , where the monoid structure comes from concatenation of loops (see ). Write for the cubical chain complex (graded cohomologically). Since is a topological monoid, the complex becomes a DG-algebra using the natural product map on cubical chains, where the DG-algebra product is given as follows: We point out that the -map when both sides are equipped with the Pontryagin product, is a DG-algebra map. In what follows, we shall also make use of an inverse to the , known as the Serre diagonal and the cubical analogue of the Alexander-Whitney map, To define this map consider the -cube with coordinates . For an ordered -element subset , , and for let be the map given in coordinates by Consider a cubical chain . If is an ordered subset of let denote its complement ordered in the natural way. Define by where the sum ranges over all ordered subsets and is the sign of the permutation . This is a strictly associative chain map inducing a quasi-isomorphism. Note also that there are obvious extensions of to several products of loop spaces. As the cubical chain complex is very large it is not the most effective complex for computation. We next discuss smaller models. Starting with a 0-reduced simplicial set with geometric realization , an explicit economical model for is obtained by taking normalized chains on the Kan loop group . We will not say much about this, but point out that is a free simplicial group such that its geometric realization is homotopy equivalent to (cf. ). Hence, by the monoidal Dold-Kan correspondence (cf. ) the normalized chains on gives a (weakly) equivalent model of . (Another similar construction is sketched in and leads to a free model.) Alternatively, one can work with CW complexes. We start with the simply connected case: for a -reduced (unique 0-cell and no 1-cells) CW-structure on the Adams-Hilton construction gives a free DG-algebra model for as follows. Denote the -cells of by , and . The Adams-Hilton construction gives a CW monoid with a single 0-cell and generating cells in dimension that is quasi-isomorphic to as a monoid (cf. ). This gives a DG-algebra structure on the free algebra: and a DG-algebra map which is a quasi-isomorphism. The differential on is generally not explicit. It is defined recursively as follows. For every 2-cell , we have . In general, assume that and have been defined on the -skeleton of , then for each -cell , with attaching map , define so that where a generator of , and to be the -chain of loops in (which then depends on earlier choices along the boundary of ). We remark that can be identified isomorphically with for a suitable coalgebra structure on the cellular chain complex . This construction can be generalized to the non-simply-connected case as follows. (See , a generalization was given earlier in , however that paper contains an error.) Begin with a -reduced CW-structure on . Denote the -cells by for . For each -cell with , we have a free variable in degree which we again denote by . For each -cell , we have two variables and in degree 0 such that . Thus, the underlying algebra is the “almost free” algebra of the form This presentation is often more efficient than the presentation one gets from the Kan loop group construction using a simplicial set presentation of . However, the differential in the Adams-Hilton model is not easy to describe explicitly. Note that we have for degree reasons. For every 2-cell , we have where represents the class of the attaching map of . The differential on higher dimensional cells is generally harder to compute and is exactly as in the simply-connected case discussed above. Augmentations correspond to solutions of the equations Since is a presentation of the fundamental group algebra , augmentations correspond exactly to local systems . We will use the cubical chain complex to define Legendrian invariants below. Cubical chains work uniformly for all spaces and are convenient for showing that the fundamental classes of moduli spaces of pseudoholomorphic disks , via evaluation maps, take values in the chain complex. The Legendrian invariants can also be studied using any of the smaller models discussed above. It is however important to note that in the non-simply connected case, we only have either weak equivalence in the homotopy category of DG-algebras or Morita equivalence of these models and the cubical chain complex . In the case that is simply-connected we can use a DG-algebra map that goes in the opposite direction to the Adams-Hilton map to pass to a more economical quasi-isomorphic model. Such a homotopy equivalence is constructed in two steps: first, in using Eilenberg-Moore methods, a DG-algebra quasi-isomorphism: is constructed where in both instances refers to the normalised singular chains. Second, using the standard -coalgebra quasi-isomorphism between the DG-coalgebra of singular chains and the coalgebra of normalised cellular chains, one obtains a DG-algebra quasi-isomorphism since we assumed that the complexes and are simply-connected. (In Section , we also give a more geometric construction of a DG-algebra quasi-isomorphism using Morse flow trees.) Similarly, if is homotopy equivalent to an Eilenberg-Maclane space , then the singular chains can be replaced with the group algebra : there exists a quasi-isomorphism of DG-algebras given by sending a -chain to its homology class, and sending all higher dimensional chains to 0. Note that this DG-algebra map exists for any space , but is a quasi-isomorphism only in the case that is homotopy equivalent to . It is often convenient to use a cofibrant (or free) replacement for . For example, if , then and a cofibrant replacement is given by the free graded algebra with the differential A DG-algebra defined over can be pulled back to a weakly equivalent DGA over this cofibrant replacement. (See for background in model categories on DG-algebras that we are using in a very simple case here.)

As above, let be a Liouville domain with (for -grading) and its contact boundary. Let be a Legendrian submanifold in where is a connected component of . Assume that is relatively spin and that its Maslov class vanishes. Let each connected component be decorated with a sign and write and for the union of the components decorated accordingly. (Our different treatments of and is natural from the point of view of handle attachments; recall from the introduction that when is a union of spheres we attach usual Lagrangian disk-handles to and handles with cotangent ends to .) When we have an exact Lagrangian filling of (relatively spin and with vanishing Maslov class), can also be decomposed into embedded components . These embedded components are not disjoint, they are allowed to intersect transversely at finitely many points. There is a bijection between and the embedded components of . We require that if two components and are boundary components of the same embedded component then either both belong to or both to . Using this property, we get a decomposition , corresponding to the decomposition . Let be the semi-simple ring generated by mutually orthogonal idempotents . If we are not given a filling of , then the index set is taken to be the connected components of instead. If we need to distinguish between the two choices, we will denote them as and . Note that there is an injective ring map which takes the idempotent corresponding to an embedded component to the sum of idempotents of its boundary components . In particular, this map turns any -bimodule into a -bimodule. Let denote the set of non-empty Reeb chords of . This is a graded set: the grading of a chord is given by where is the Conley-Zehnder grading, see Section . (With this convention, the unique chord of the standard Legendrian unknot in has and for the corresponding Legendrian unknot in with one Reeb chord , . See also Rmk. .) Note that is a -bimodule, where corresponds to the set of Reeb chords from to . The underlying algebra of the standard Chekanov-Eliashberg DG-algebra is generated freely by over . We need to modify this in the case is non-empty to incorporate chains in the based loop space of for . Let us first do this using cubical chains. For each , consider the cubical chains as a -algebra by requiring that the left or right action of is trivial except if when it acts as identity. Let be the algebra over given by freely adjoining elements of to the union of for . Thus an element of is a word in Reeb chords and chains on based loops of for that respects the -bimodule structure. Now the differential on is defined by extending the differential on the cubical complexes for . Since the elements of are added freely, it suffices to describe the differential on a single Reeb chord and extend it by the graded Leibniz rule. The differential on a Reeb chord decomposes to a sum where for any Reeb chord only finitely many are non-zero. The operations are defined as follows. Consider moduli spaces of holomorphic disks with positive puncture at , see Section for definitions and notation. More precisely, consider Reeb chords such that is a composable word and let . Consider the disk with one distinguished positive puncture and negative punctures (across which the boundary numbering is constant in the terminology of Section ). Consider the moduli space . Theorems and imply that this is a smooth orientable manifold with a natural compactification as a stratified space that carries a fundamental chain. It follows that, via the evaluation map at a point in the boundary arcs of , parameterizes a chain of paths in the -fold product , which after adding reference paths to the base point becomes chain of based loops in . We treat two cases separately. First, if all boundary components of map to components in then we let where is the algebraic number of -components in the moduli space. Second, if some boundary component maps to a component in then we write for the chain or paths in , where we separate the components in the product by the Reeb chords : where are the components of the fundamental chain . Further, we write for each boundary component that maps to a component in in between the Reeb chords as above. A subtle point here is that the moduli space naturally gives rise to a chain in the rather than . Note that are simply components of , they are not considered as chains. To separate these out we apply the cubical Alexander-Whitney map, recalled in Section : With these conventions we then define for , where we separate the components of the tensor product by the Reeb chords in in analogy with the notation for the product chain and where is the Serre diagonal. The output of is thus a sum of alternating words of chains of loops in and Reeb chords, and is an operation of degree on . We point out that if there are components then higher dimensional moduli spaces contribute to the differential (unlike the case when ). Note also that it is possible to have holomorphic disks contributing to , which means that the chord is the positive puncture of a disk without negative punctures. Let be the map extended to by the graded Leibniz rule. Then is a differential, . We call with the differential the [**Chekanov-Eliashberg DG-algebra**]{}. When , was called in - this is cohomologically graded version of the usual Legendrian homology algebra in . By definition, we have . In case there are only components in involved the result follows from standard arguments involving the boundary of 1-dimensional moduli spaces. Consider therefore the case when there are chains in the loop space involved. Let . The -dimensional moduli space contributes to . Its boundary consists of broken curves with one level of dimension and one of dimension for , we find, with denoting the natural tensor extension of the boundary operator in singular homology over boundary components involved in , that where denotes the Pontryagin product, where , and . We next apply the cubical Alexander-Whitney map to this formula to deduce where we used that the is a chain map and is compatible with the product. The fact that is a chain map is well known. We verify that it is compatible with the product below. It follows that the terms contributing to which arises from the differential acting on chains and acting on Reeb chords cancel. It remains to check that is compatible with the products, to this end we provide the simplest non-trivial case, the general case is done similarly. Thus, we need to check that the following compositions agree: and This is easily checked by evaluating it on a test chain . Note that this uses the fact that the cubical chain complex is a quotient. Namely, degenerate cubical chains are divided out. As mentioned in the introduction we relate as defined above to a parallel copies version of the same algebra which is defined solely in terms of rigid moduli spaces. In order to do so it is convenient to use a topologically simpler but algebraically more complicated model of , defined as follows. The generating set of our algebra is extended to chains in the product , where we separate the coordinate functions by Reeb chords. We define the product of two such chains by taking the Pontryagin product of the chains at adjacent factors giving an operation The differential on this version of is then defined by the singular differential one the chain and as on Reeb chord generators. (In other words we define it as above but disregard the diagonal approximation.) It follows from the Künneth formula that the two versions of are quasi-isomorphic. Although, the definitions of given above works generally, from a computational perspective, it is hard to get our hands on, as the cubical chain complexes have uncountably many elements. Next, we provide a modification of the definition that gives a quasi-isomorphic DG-algebra, under the assumption that for each , there exists a DG-algebra quasi-isomorphism where is a DG-algebra structure on a free algebra generated by a graded finite set . For example, as discussed in Section , such a DG-algebra map exists when is simply-connected (or if is a space, one can first work with the group ring and base-change to a cofibrant replacement of it). We define a graded quiver with vertex set and arrows in correspondence with More precisely, there are arrows from vertex to corresponding to the set of Reeb chords from to . In addition, for each , there are arrows from to corresponding to the elements in . Let be the graded -bimodule generated by . Thus, there is one generator for each arrow in and an idempotent for each vertex and write for the submodule without the idempotents. Let be -algebra given by the tensor algebra Recall that the path algebra of a quiver is defined as a vector space having all paths in the quiver as basis (including, for each vertex an idempotent ), and multiplication given by concatenation of paths. Thus, the -bimodule is the path algebra of the quiver where the grading of each arrow is shifted up by . Just like in the cobar construction we write elements in as where . Next, we equip the -algebra with a differential using the moduli spaces of holomorphic disks defined in Section . This differential is induced by operations where , that give the structure of an coalgebra if . Consider a generator of . If it is a generator of the free model of for some component then we define where is the co-product that corresponds to homogeneous piece of the differential in the free model of . If it is a Reeb chord the define as before using moduli spaces but now take the image of all the singular chains in under the map . Since the map is a DG-algebra map, the proof that is differential on is the same. Furthermore, since is a quasi-isomorphism, we get a quasi-isomorphic chain complex if we use coefficients instead of . From now on, unless otherwise specified, we will always assume that we work with a free (over ) model of . If there exists an augmentation , then there is a change of coordinates which turn into a coalgebra. More precisely, consider the restriction of , , where we think of as the degree polynomials in . Define Note that is generated idempotents and by , where ranges over the generators of . Let be the -algebra automorphism defined on generators as . Define the operations by The operations satisfy the -coalgebra relations and with these operations is a coaugmented conilpotent coalgebra. Let denote the differential on and let be a generator of . Since is a augmentation, and it follows that . The coalgebra relations then follows by combining the equation from Theorem with the automorphism . The coaugmentation is simply the inclusion of . The fact that is conilpotent follows from Stokes’ theorem: the sum of the actions of the Reeb chords at the negative end of a disk contributing to the differential is bounded above by the action of the Reeb chord at the positive end. This gives the desired finiteness. Note that if the original operation on equals then the map which takes all generators of to is an augmentation and in this case by construction. If there is an augmentation then can be expressed as the cobar construction of a coalgebra: by construction We next consider the -linear dual of . It follows from Section that this is an augmented -algebra. We call it the LEGENDRIAN -ALGEBRA. In case , it can be shown that this algebra can be obtained from the endomorphism algebra of the augmentation in category of by adjoining a unit to it, but is, in general, different from the endomorphism algebra in the category of . Given an augmentation , we define the [**completed Chekanov-Eliashberg DG-algebra**]{} to be . The underlying -algebra is the completed tensor algebra: where is the ideal determined by the natural augmentation. Note that there is a natural chain map: To illustrate the various gradings, the unique Reeb chord for the standard Legendrian unknot in has degree is in , in and in (while it is in ). Therefore, we have the graded isomorphisms: , and .

In this section we will describe the perturbation scheme we will use to define various version of Lagrangian Floer cohomology. For exact Lagrangian submanifolds with Legendrian boundary we get an induced perturbation scheme for the Legendrian boundary that will allow us to define a simpler version of the Chekanov-Eliashberg algebra which is isomorphic to it in case the Legendrian is simply connected. Let be a Weinstein manifold and let be an exact Lagrangian submanifold with Legendrian boundary . We assume that is embedded but allow to be a several component Lagrangian with components that intersect transversely. Assume that the components of are decorated with signs and write and for the union of the components decorated and , respectively. We will use specific families of Morse functions to shift Lagrangian and Legendrian submanifolds off of themselves in order to relate holomorphic curve theory to Morse theory, and to perform Floer cohomology calculations without Hamiltonian perturbations. We consider a collection of pairs of Morse functions , where and , which have the following properties. Write and for the ends of and , respectively. In the end, with coordinates , we require that all pairs satisfy, and that does not have any local maxima. We next discuss further restrictions related to critical points. Let be any pair of positive Morse functions as above. Let be the critical points of and let be the critical points of . Fix disjoint coordinate balls around and of such that and are given by a quadratic polynomial in these coordinates. Fix small and such that Let be another pair of positive Morse functions with respectively critical points and , where Let and fix coordinate balls and such that Finally, we make sure that , and which we obtain by over all scaling. Note that we might have to shrink after scaling. We continue inductively and construct a family of pairs , of positive Morse functions with the following properties. Each has critical points , each has critical points . There is and disjoint coordinate balls around and around such that Furthermore, the following hold and , , and . We next take into account the sign decoration. Assume that is non-empty. In this case we first construct functions exactly as above on all components of . The actual functions on are then on and on . We will use the pair of Morse functions Consider a cotangent neighborhood of which agrees with the symplectization of the -jet space of at infinity. Using this neighborhood we extend the Morse function trivially in the auxiliary directions and let be the time flow of the Hamiltonian vector field of the function . Let . Then has Legendrian boundary which is the cylinder over the 1-jet graph of the function on . Intersection points corresponds to intersection between the components of and critical points of . Since we find that from the point of view of , can be viewed as a small perturbation of . In particular, if then is transverse and there is a unique intersection point near each intersection point in which corresponds to critical points of and self-intersections of . Similarly, at infinity Reeb chords in a small neighborhood of connect to , and there is a unique transverse such chord near each critical point , and there are no local Reeb chords connecting to if . In Sections and we will also apply this construction to Lagrangian submanifolds , where is a Weinstein cobordism with both positive and negative ends. Our Lagrangian submanifolds that will be equipped with systems of parallel copies will however have only positive ends in that case and the above discussion applies without change. See Remark for a version when both positive and negative ends are perturbed.

We will relate the Legendrian invariants and to Floer (co)homology of exact Lagrangian submanifolds. When studying Lagrangian Floer (co)homology we employ the technique of parallel copies to achieve transversality and it will be convenient to express the Legendrian invariants in the same language. As it turns out, in the case that the Legendrians are simply connected this technique leads to a simpler formulation of the theory which incorporates a model of chains on the based loop space automatically. Recall that Lagrangian fillings of Legendrian submanifolds induce augmentations, which after change of variables lead to non-curved Legendrian co-algebras. Geometrically, this means that one uses anchored holomorphic disks. We will assume that an augmentation of has been fixed in this section and all disks considered will be anchored with respect to this augmentation. We now turn to the description of this theory in the Legendrian setting. Let be as above with decomposition . Fix a Morse function which is positive on and negative on . Use it as described in Section to construct a system of parallel copies of . Let , , and be as above. Let denote the Reeb chords connecting to that lie in a small neighborhood of . By construction there is then a natural 1-1 correspondence between and the set of critical points of on . (Since shifts in the negative Reeb direction there are no such short chords near .) Write and think of chords in as connecting a component to itself. Again the set is a graded set: Reeb chords are graded as above and the grading of a short chord equals the negative of the Morse index of the critical point of corresponding to . We define a graded quiver with vertex set and arrows in correspondence with More precisely, there are arrows from vertex to corresponding to the set of Reeb chords from to if and corresponding to short Reeb chords from to if . Let be the graded -bimodule generated by . We define an coalgebra structure on given by operations as follows. Given a chord (input) and a chords (outputs), we consider the disk with distinguished puncture at and an STRICTLY INCREASING boundary decoration . Let . Consider the moduli space . We write for the algebraic number of -components in this moduli space provided and otherwise. Define for , where . This gives an operation of degree on . Note that trivially, since the decoration is strictly increasing. It is not a priori clear that the maps are well-defined as the sum may involve infinitely many terms. This can be avoided easily if are simply-connected for . Namely, the simply-connectedness of guarantees that the short chords cost index, whereas the long chords cost energy. In the non-simply connected case, we will only consider a completed version of where infinite expressions are allowed. Suppose is simply-connected or more generally, suppose that factorizes through the natural inclusion for all , then equipped with the operations is an coalgebra. Recall that the moduli spaces involved in the definition of the operations are moduli spaces of anchored disks, where we use the augmentation induced by the filling . Consider a 1-dimensional moduli space and note that its boundary consists of two level rigid disks by Theorems and . There are two cases, either the levels are joined at a chord connecting the same copy of to itself or the chord connects distinct copies. Since we count anchored disks and since the augmentation satisfies the chain map equation, the first type of breaking cancels algebraically. Theorem then shows that there are canonical identifications between moduli spaces for different increasing numberings and the proof follows since the second type of breakings are exactly what contributes to the coalgebra relations and are then in algebraic one to one correspondence with the endpoints of an oriented compact 1-manifold. We next introduce the parallel copies version of the Chekanov-Eliashberg algebra. Consider a generator of which is a small Reeb chord that corresponds to a critical point of the Morse function . The coalgebra operations then counts holomorphic disks with positive puncture at which, by an action argument, must lie in a small neighborhood of . In particular, rigid such holomorphic disks are in natural correspondence with rigid Morse flow trees. It follows from this that if is the minimum of the Morse function on the component then , , and for . Furthermore, if is any other generator corresponding to an arrow from to then and does not contain any factor for . The equations involving only follows by the description of flow trees emanating from a minimum, the other equations follows from the fact that any rigid disk with an output puncture at the minimum must correspond to a flow line attached to a trivial strip, for dimensional reasons. It then follows that there is a coaugmentation If is simply-connected, the parallel copies Chekanov-Eliashberg DG-algebra is If is not simply-connected, then we define the completed DG-algebra with the differential induced from the operations . As in the case with loop space coefficients we also define the Legendrian -algebra of as the linear dual of the Legendrian co-algebra: Note that since there is no finiteness condition necessary for , this is well-defined for all without any need to complete.

outline.text: Isomorphism between Chekanov-Eliashberg algebras in the simply connected case
outline._note: We next show that if is simply connected then is in fact isomorphic to . To this end we first establish a Morse theoretic version of Adams result mentioned in the introduction, which here corresponds to the purely local situation of the zero-section in a 1-jet space. Let be a SIMPLY-CONNECTED smooth manifold with a base point . Fix a system of positive Morse functions , and assume that the functions have only one minimum and no index one critical points. (This can always be arranged by handle cancellation if , see Remarks and for the lower dimensional case.) We will first discuss a Morse flow tree model for chains on that we denote . Our treatment of Morse flow trees follows . Consider a strip or half-strip with coordinates and with slits along , , and in the half-strip case. In the half strip case the vertical segment is a finite end that will be an used as an input, and we do not consider it as a part of the boundary of the strip with slits. In the strip case, the input is at the puncture , and in both cases we call punctures at output. Order the boundary components according to the positive boundary orientation of the disk with punctures starting from the input and decorate its boundary components by a strictly increasing sequence of positive integers . Let denote this decoration. Cutting the strip by line segments , , subdivides it into STRIP REGIONS of the form , where , , and and with a numbering on each boundary component and . A flow tree is a continuous map from a strip with slits into which in each strip region depends only on the first coordinate and there satisfies the gradient equation where is the numbering of the upper horizontal boundary of the strip region and that of the lower. A partial flow tree is defined analogously except that the domain is a half-strip with slits . If is a critical point of then we let denote the negative Morse index of . If is a word of critical points of then the space of flow trees with input puncture at and output punctures , in the order induced by the boundary orientation, has dimension For sufficiently small perturbing system of Morse functions , the space of flow trees is independent of the increasing boundary decoration . Let denote the -module generated by critical points of and equip with the structure of a coalgebra with operations given by where the sum ranges over all of word length . It is not hard to see that the boundary of a 1-dimensional space of flow trees consists of broken rigid flow trees from which it follows that the operations satisfy the coalgebra relations. Furthermore, the coalgebra has a natural co-unit, the critical point which is the minimum of . We will call this critical point the CO-UNIT CRITICAL POINT. We say that a flow tree with no puncture mapping to the co-unit critical point is CO-UNIT FREE. The coalgebra is in fact known to agree with the Floer coalgebra , where we view as the zero section in its own cotangent bundle as follows. Let be the system of parallel copies of the -section corresponding to the system of functions . Then by a special case of (the case when fronts have no singularities at all), there is, for all sufficiently small shifts, a natural one to one correspondence between rigid holomorphic disks with boundary on and Morse flow trees in determined by . This gives a chain isomorphism . We now return to the Morse theoretic approach to Adams’ result. We will define a map in terms of the operation of attaching co-unit free partial flow trees to Moore loops , , based at , parameterized by a simplex, . To define this operation we will use the following notion: we say that a partial flow tree parameterized by a half-strip starts at a point if its input puncture maps to , . We define the map by counting rigid loops with flow trees in cubical simplices : The map is defined only for chains that are suitably transverse to the Morse flow trees defined by the system of shifting functions . Since the Morse functions do not have any index one critical points a partial flow tree has at most punctures. There is a natural evaluation map on partial flow trees that takes a flow tree to the location of its positive puncture. The image of this map for partial flow trees not involving the minimum is a stratified space of codimension one and by definition of the perturbation scheme the corresponding set for partial flow trees defined by distinct boundary numberings lie arbitrarily close to each other. The map above is defined for chains of loops with evaluation maps that are smooth and transverse to this stratified subset. It is straightforward to see that any chain of loops is homotopic to such a transverse chain and that any two transverse chains that are homologous are homologous through a transverse chain of loops. This means that we can replace all chains by chains that represent these transversality conditions. In order to connect this to the path loop fibration we consider a similar map where denotes the canonical twisting cochain of the cobar construction and the based path space. The map again counts rigid paths with flow trees, where a path with flow trees is defined as a loop with flow trees except that we also attach a flow tree at the endpoint of the path. Furthermore, the last puncture in the flow tree attached at the endpoint is the distinguished last factor and is allowed to be the co-unit critical point. (Other punctures are still not the co-unit critical point, which means that flow trees before the last are still co-unit free and that in the last flow tree only the last puncture is allowed to be the co-unit). We point out that the differential on the twisted complex acting on the last factor in the right hand side counts trees where the last puncture is distinguished. The maps and are chain maps. To see this note that the contributions to the chain map equation in both cases correspond to the boundary of an oriented compact 1-dimensional manifold. The codimension one boundary of corresponds either to the loop or path moving to the boundary of or to the breaking of a flow tree at a critical point. Instances when two trees are attached at the same point are naturally interior points of the moduli space where the disks with slits joins to a new disk with a slit of width equal to the sum of the widths. The pre-twisting cochain can now be seen to arise via SFT-stretching as follows. Consider the first component of the -map above and a holomorphic disk contributing to it. Now stretch the lower end of the cobordism. Then by SFT-compactness the curves contributing to breaks up into a curve contributing to the map followed by the twisting cochain at each negative puncture. Noting that are the only low energy generators, it follows that the map induces a map of the high energy quotient into and we can write the induced map as .
In this section we compute Legendrian and Lagrangian invariants in a number of concrete examples.

Consider the Legendrian unknot for with its standard filling . Then can be represented as a standard unknot in a small Darboux chart which has effectively only one Reeb chord with respect to the standard Reeb flow on , see . We work over a field . Consider first the case when is decorated by . We then have with all coalgebra maps trivial, except for which we have: by the co-unitality. Using a Morse function on with a unique local maximum and which decreases in the end corresponding to shift in the negative Reeb direction, we have Let be the Adams-Floer algebra, where degree of is now shifted up by 1. Then, we have the twisting cochain Here the disk with input and output corresponds to the family of disks with positive puncture at that sweeps once. (The case of is drawn in Figure ( )).
