outline.text: Geometric twisting cochain for the Hopf link
outline._note: (-1.6,0.93) to (-2.3,0); (-1.4,1) to (-0.3,0.3); (-1.6,-0.93)to (-2.3,0); (-1.4,-1)to (-0.25,-0.25) ; (1.5,1) to (0.3,0.3); (1.5,-1)to (2.3,0); (1.5,1) to (1.9,0.8); (2.05,0.65) to (2.3,0); (1.5,-1)to (0.3,-0.3) ; (-0.3,0.3) to (0.3,-0.3); (-0.15,-0.15) to (-0.05,-0.05); (0.05,0.05) to (0.3,0.3); (-1.5,1) to (-2.3,0); (-1.5,1) to (-0.3,0.3); (-1.5,-1)to (-2.3,0); (-1.5,-1)to (-0.3,-0.3) ; (2,1.25) to (0.25,0.25); (2,-1.25)to (2.95,0); (2,1.25) to (2.5,0.95); (2.65,0.8) to (2.95,0); (2,-1.25)to (0.3,-0.3) ; (-0.3,0.3) to (0.3,-0.3); (-0.3,-0.3) to (-0.05,-0.05); (0.05,0.05) to (0.15,0.15); (2.5,1) to (1.7,0); (2.5,-1) to (2.32,-0.95); (2.2,-0.87) to (2.07,-0.77); (1.95,-0.65) to (1.7,0); (2.5,1) to (3.7,0.3); (2.5,-1)to (3.7,-0.3) ; (5.5,1) to (6.3,0); (5.5,1) to (4.3,0.3); (6.3,0)to (5.5,-1); (5.5,-1)to (4.3,-0.3) ; (3.7,0.3) to (4.3,-0.3); (3.7,-0.3) to (3.9,-0.1); (4.1,0.1) to (4.3,0.3); at (0.3,0) ; at (1.7,0.7) ; at (1.7,-0.7) ; at (4,0.3) ; at (-1.5,1.2) ; at (-1.5,-1.2) ; In this section we carry out the geometric calculation of the twisting cochain for the Hopf link. As explained we cannot directly calculate the twisting cochain into the Legendrian coalgebra with coefficients in chains of the based loop space. We can however calculate the corresponding twisting cochain when we replace chains on the based loop space with the Morse theory of parallel copies for the components decorated by a positive sign. To carry out the calculation we pick a Morse function on the component with on minimum and a maximum . We place them on the circle and choose parallel copies as shown in Figure . The parallel copies algebra is where we use notation for Reeb chords and Floer cohomology generators as in Section . The differential is Passing to means dividing out by the cokernel of the coaugmentation that takes to . This gives the algebra and the differential becomes The twisting cochain is induced from a map that counts holomorphic disks with one positive puncture and boundary on , and with several punctures at Lagrangian intersection points in the compact part, see . In the current example it is straightforward to find these disk. Note first that by general properties, see Proposition , where is the idempotent corresponding to the minimum of the shifting Morse function on . The holomorphic disk corresponds to a Morse flow line connecting to . We next consider and . Consider first the moduli spaces of holomorphic disks with a positive puncture at and boundary on . As in the case of the unknot this moduli space sweeps . On both and the shifting functions have one critical point, on it is a minimum and on a maximum. The maximum is constraining for the map into the linear dual of , whereas the minimum is not. We find that The space give further information of the twisting co-chain as follows. Note that as the evaluation map hits the double point one can glue on a constant disk. These broken disks are also the boundary of the 1-dimensional moduli spaces and . The other end of these moduli spaces correspond to broken disks with one level in the symplectization, a disk in in the former case and in in the latter, and two disks one in and one in attached at its negative end. The last disks contribute to and we conclude that Finally, we compute . Since is a small chord corresponding to a critical point at infinity of the shifting Morse function the only contributions to comes from small holomorphic disks that are controlled by the Morse theory. It is straightforward to check that the only rigid disk corresponds to a flow line in connecting to the intersection point and that this flow line corresponds to a holomorphic triangle in . It follows that The actual twisting co-chain takes the cokernel of the co-augmentation into the cokernel of the co-units. Concretely, this means disregarding and , and we get We point out that the parallel copies algebra is defined using a fixed augmentation (in the current example the zero augmentation) on the one copy version of . Here this is reflected in the change of variables .

We will consider a Legendrian embedding , where the ambient space is standard contact -space with coordinates and contact form . We will define it by describing its front in . To this end consider first the following construction of the front of the Legendrian unknot in . Take a disk lying in . Think of it as having multiplicity two and lift one of the sheets up in the auxiliary -direction (with coordinate ) keeping it fixed along the boundary. In this way we construct the front of the standard unknot with Reeb chord at the maximum distance between the two sheets and a cusp edge along the boundary of . Consider now instead the base and the standard embedding of the -dimensional sphere into this space. A tubular neighborhood of this embedding has the form with fibers . Now take two copies of this tubular neighborhood and repeat the above construction for the in each fiber. The result is the front of a Legendrian with an Bott-family of Reeb chords corresponding to the maxima in fibers. Figure shows this front after Morse perturbation. The resulting Legendrian has only two Reeb chords. We denote them of grading and of grading . Note also that has an exact Lagrangian filling . Let be a tree with vertex set . For each , let be a compact simply-connected manifold of dimension . We will see that duality holds between the wrapped and the compact Fukaya categories of the symplectic manifold obtained by plumbing the collection of according to the tree . As usual, we take the pre-surgery perspective. Hence, consider a handle decomposition of each with a unique top-dimensional -handle. Removing this handle, we get manifolds with spherical boundary . Let be the subcritical Weinstein manifold obtained by plumbing the cotangent bundles according to the tree . We take the plumbing region to be away from the boundary of . Write for the Legendrian in the boundary of the subcritical Weinstein manifold which is filled by the Lagrangian . Equip the components of with either or labeling. If and is simply-connected for each , then and are Koszul dual. Consider first the case . Pick a handle decomposition of without - and -handles. The existence of such a handle decomposition is equivalent to simply-connectivity in high dimensions by the work of Smale. Consider the corresponding Weinstein handle decomposition of . Attaching a -handle alters the Legendrian boundary by surgery and adds Reeb chords in the co-core sphere of the handle of grading and it follows that all Reeb chords of have grading . To construct , we perform a version of boundary connected sum as follows. For each edge in we pick a -ball with two transversely intersecting Lagrangian disks that intersect the boundary sphere in a standard Legendrian Hopf link . We then make boundary connected sum adding to join the according to the tree. This adds Reeb chords of index in the boundary connected sum handles and further Reeb chords corresponding to the Reeb chords of each Hopf link, which effectively has four Reeb chords: two Reeb chords connecting the unknot components to themselves of grading and two mixed Reeb chords connecting distinct components. We can pick gradings so that the gradings of these two mixed chords are and for any , where the first Reeb chord goes from the component closest to priori fixed root of the tree to the one further from it and the other in the opposite direction. Taking between and we find that is simply connected as is . The result then follows from Theorem . For , we can stabilize by multiplying by as described in Remarks and to get 1-reduced versions of the Legendrian and Lagrangian algebras and then use the above argument. Finally for , the assumptions of Theorem does not hold but we recall from Remark that to apply the duality result from Theorem all we really need is that is locally finite. This is easily seen to be the case in our case, since the plumbing is according to a tree (which by definition has no cycles) and for any word of Reeb chords that do not consist of connecting Reeb chords going away from the root of the tree the grading has to increase with the size of the word. Alternatively, in this case we know by Perelman’s theorem that we can take as a link of standard Legendrian spheres linked according to the tree as Hopf links and can be seen to be locally finite directly. The case corresponds to plumbing of copies of . This case was studied in and a version of the duality result still holds, at least when . However, the above argument fails in that case and a more complicated argument using an additional grading is used in . Also a set of examples for are studied in , where the plumbing tree is a star and the corresponding symplectic manifolds is a punctured torus. The duality still holds in this case, even though this is a plumbing of ’s (not simply-connected). The proof of duality given in uses homological mirror symmetry.

(-1.5,1) to (-2.3,0); (-1.5,1) to (-0.3,0.3); (-1.5,-1)to (-2.3,0); (-1.5,-1)to (-0.3,-0.3) ; (1.4,1.7) to (0.3,0.3); (1.4,1.7) to (1.8,1.1); (2.05,0.85) to (1.8,-0.3); (2.05,-0.35) to (1.8,-1.5); (1.8,-1.5)to (1.5,-1.7) ; (1.5,-1.7)to (0.3,-0.3) ; (-0.3,0.3) to (0.3,-0.3); (-0.3,-0.3) to (-0.1,-0.1); (0.1,0.1) to (0.3,0.3); (2.5,1.7) to (1.8,0.9); (1.8,0.9)to (1.8,-0.1); (1.8,-0.3)to (1.8,-1.3); (2.05,-1.45)to (2.5,-1.7); (2.5,1.7) to (3.7,0.3); (2.5,-1.7)to (3.7,-0.3) ; (5.5,1) to (6.3,0); (5.5,1) to (4.3,0.3); (6.3,0)to (5.5,-1); (5.5,-1)to (4.3,-0.3) ; (3.7,0.3) to (4.3,-0.3); (3.7,-0.3) to (3.9,-0.1); (4.1,0.1) to (4.3,0.3); at (0,0.3) ; at (1.5,1) ; at (1.5,-0.25) ; at (1.5,-1.4) ; at (4,0.3) ; Consider the standard Legendrian trefoil described in Figure . Let us first consider the case when is marked . With respect to the standard choice of orientation datum, the Chekanov-Eliashberg DG-algebra is then given by the free algebra and the non-trivial part of the differential can be read from Figure as follows: It is well known that has an exact Lagrangian torus filling. (In fact, there are at least five of them, see ). Any of these can be obtained by doing surgery (pinch move) at , and in some order. Corresponding augmentations are given by their values subject to the condition: Note that since is not simply-connected, Theorem does not apply here. In fact, duality does not hold in this example. However, Theorem shows that there is a quasi-isomorphisms of completions where the latter is a power series ring in two commuting variables concentrated in degree 0. Thus, the completion map composed with the twisting cochain gives an algebra map: We claim that this map is injective. Indeed, observe that is a commutative algebra: and thus, commutes with in homology. Using this, one shows similarly that commutes with and , see . Hence, we have a completion map from a commutative ring to its completion It is a well known theorem, known as Krull intersection theorem, in commutative algebra that for any commutative Noetherian ring which is an integral domain the completion map is injective. Thus, even though duality fails in this example, partial information can still be obtained by considering completions. We next describe the twisting cochain for one of the Lagrangian fillings of . More precisely, we choose the filling which is obtained by pinching first at , then at , then at , and finally filling the resulting unknots with Lagrangian disks, see . We think of the Lagrangian filling in as two disks connected by three twisted bands corresponding to the three pinchings. We next consider moduli spaces of holomorphic disks with boundary in . Here gives a description in terms of Morse flow trees which gives the following: consists of one disk, . consists of two disks, and . consists of two disks, and The boundaries of these disks are as follows. is fiber in the first twisted band. is a fiber in the second twisted band, and runs across the first and the second twisted band. is a fiber in the third twisted band, and runs across the second and the third twisted bands. We next describe the moduli spaces , in a completely analogous manner. The space has four components, all diffeomorphic to intervals, as follows: with one boundary point the disk in with attached, and the other the disk in with , , and attached. with one boundary point the disk in with attached, and the other the disk in with , , and attached. with one boundary point the disk in with attached, and the other the disk in with , , and attached. with one boundary point the disk in and the other the disk in with , , and attached. Here the disks in sweeps the right hand disk of , whereas the evaluation maps of , does not map surjectively onto either disk. The moduli space also has four components only one of which sweeps the left hand disk of . In order to compute the Floer cohomology we pick a Morse function with one maximum and two saddle points and . Letting the maximum lie in the right hand disk we find: since the only way to rigidify a disk of dimension one is that its boundary passes the maximum . The twisting cochain can now in principle be computed from the moduli spaces described above by attaching flow trees. To get an algebraically feasible twisting co-chain we first arrange the perturbation scheme so that where the first term is with a flow line and the second with a flow tree, and next so that the disk with a flow line contributes, other contributions cancel (the disk with two flow lines and the same disk with a flow tree, the two distinct disks with one flow lines). Remaining parts of the twisting cochain are now determined from the co-product in the Floer homology: the twisting cochain equation, and the sweeping property of , as follows: and It is possible to check that these power series agree with the geometric count. We leave out the details but describe the mechanism. In order to arrange that only one flow line can be attached to we order the stable manifolds of the flow line of the parallel copies so that if a flow line (or flow tree) between copy and is attached then following we already passed all intersections with stable manifolds between copy and for . Now, if the disk intersects the collection of stable manifolds in the opposite direction this means that we can jump down in all ways, which then gives the desired power series. We finish this section by a brief discussion of the case decorated by and parallel copies. As usual this introduces two extra generators in addition to the Reeb chords above in , , and , , where is the counit corresponding to the minimum of the shifting function and is the maximum. In the reduced coalgebra (disregarding ) we get the new differential (using the augmentation above to change coordinates): In this case is defined instead by choosing a shifting function that increases at infinity, and is generated by the unit , and , with . The new twisting cochain is and is exactly as above, after the substitutions , .

Let be a Legendrian -submanifold with in the boundary of a Weinstein -manifold that bounds an exact Lagrangian . Assume that and that the Maslov class of vanishes and that is relatively spin. Decorate by . Our next result shows that if the symplectic homology of vanishes and if all Reeb chords of have negative grading as generators of then is determined by the topology of and conversely. If is a sphere then we write for the closed manifold obtained by adding a disk to along . Suppose that is simply-connected. Assume that and that is supported in degrees . Then is simply connected. Moreover, if is a sphere then is isomorphic to . Consider the wrapped Floer cohomology of with coefficients in . Using our model for wrapped Floer cohomology in Section , a chain complex which calculates can be described as follows. Let and let be a parallel copy of shifted in the negative Reeb direction at infinity. The complex is then generated over by the intersection points in which we call the Morse generators and the Reeb chords starting on and ending on . The differential of a generator counts the usual rigid holomorphic strips, keeping track of the homotopy class of the loop obtained from the boundary component of the disk in completed by the reference paths connecting Reeb chord endpoints and intersection points to the base point. We point out that since there are no Reeb chords of degree the augmentation induced by is trivial and the high energy part of the differential on counts honest holomorphic strips (without extra negative punctures at augmented Reeb chords). As for usual wrapped Floer homology, is naturally a module over symplectic cohomology and hence vanishes. We next describe a geometric version of the complex that we call and that also computes . Let denote the universal covering of and let . Pick a Morse function with the following properties has exactly one local maximum . has no index critical points. has no local minima. is constant on where it attains its global minimum and if is the unit normal vector field along then . The generators of are of two types The preimages of end points of Reeb chords in under graded as the corresponding Reeb chord in . The critical points of the Morse function graded by the negative of the Morse index. Let denote the Morse chain complex of with cohomological grading, with generators as in and differential which counts negative gradient flow lines. Then is supported in degrees with and . Let denote the complex generated by the generators of type and equip it with the differential that counts lifts of the boundary of holomorphic strips in the symplectization interpolating between Reeb chords. (This corresponds naturally to the high-energy part of the differential on .) By our assumption on Reeb chord grading the grading of supported in degrees where . We now define the complex with differential where and are the differentials on and and where counts rigid lifts of disks with flow lines of attached. (This is the linear part of the map in .) The homology of is then isomorphic to . To see this note that we can describe exactly as just replacing the Morse function above with a Morse function , where is a Morse function on without minimum and with the required boundary behavior. Thus passing from to corresponds to deforming the Morse function on and it is well known that this induces a homotopy of complexes. In particular is acyclic. We next want to show that or equivalently that the map has degree one. To show this we first observe that since there are no Reeb chords of grading the augmentation of is trivial and the differential on counts honest holomorphic strips in the symplectization. This in turn means that the whole boundary of any holomorphic strip contributing to actually lies in and therefore cannot pick up any non-trivial -coefficient. Consider the following part of the chain complex : where we use that for and . It follows from the above discussion and the vanishing of the wrapped homology with trivial coefficients that that the cohomology in degree has one generator for each non-trivial element in . On the other hand and we conclude that . The statement about the isomorphism class of then follows from Corollary .

Consider as above a Weinstein manifold with an exact Lagrangian submanifold , which outside a compact agrees with the positive part of the symplectization of the contact manifold with Legendrian submanifold . We assume that the Maslov class of vanishes and that is relatively spin. We will consider several versions of boundary punctured holomorphic disks with boundary on . The most basic disks we consider will lie either in or in the symplectization . We call the former FILLING DISKS and the latter SYMPLECTIZATION DISKS. We will also consider a more general setting where, like in the symplectization, disks may have both positive and negative punctures. Here we assume that is a Weinstein cobordism with negative end and positive end , where is a contact manifold and is a Legendrian submanifold. More specifically we will consider a Lagrangian with positive end and empty negative end and a Lagrangian with negative end and empty positive end. We further assume that there is a natural one-to-one correspondence between the components of of and of , , and that corresponding components and intersect transversely in one point and that if . We call disks in COBORDISM DISKS. Following , all symplectization and cobordism disks we consider will be anchored. This means that the actual disks we consider have, except for their boundary punctures, also additional interior punctures where the maps are asymptotic to Reeb orbits at the negative end. An anchored disk is such a disk completed by rigid holomorphic planes in at all its negative interior punctures, see Figure . We will count rigid disks as well as use moduli spaces of disks to parameterize chains of boundary paths which then requires studying anchored disks. Although, standard arguments using classical methods allow us to prove transversality for the disks with boundary punctures that we consider, anchored disks requires transversality and gluing also for holomorphic planes in and that requires an abstract perturbation scheme. We will not enter any detailed discussion of this subject in this paper, but would like to point out that any of the approaches could be used to prove the required abstract perturbation results and the results that we establish in this paper are independent of the detailed nature of the perturbation scheme. (2,3) to (1.6,0.95); (1.53,0.55) to (1.5,0); (2,0) to (2.5,0); (3,0) to (3.5,0); (2.5,3) to (4,0); (1.5,0) to (2,0); (2.5,0) to (3,0); (3.5,0) to (4,0); (2,3) to (2.5,3); (2.2,1.5) to (-0.5,0); (2.7,1.5) to (1,0); (0.5,0) to (0,0); (-0.5,0) to (0,0); (-0.5,0) to (0,0); (0.5,0) to (1,0); (0.5,0) to (1,0); (-0.5,-0.35) to (0,-0.35); (-0.5,-0.35) to (0,-0.35); (0.5,-0.35) to (1,-0.35); (0.5,-0.35) to (1,-0.35); (-0.5,-0.35) to (-0.25,-0.7); (0,-0.35) to (-0.25,-0.7); (0.5,-0.35) to (0.75,-0.7); (1,-0.35) to (0.75,-0.7); Consider a system of parallel copies , where , as in Section . We first discuss numberings that determine the boundary conditions of our holomorphic disks. Let denote the unit disk in the complex plane with boundary punctures . One of the boundary punctures is distinguished. We choose notation so that is distinguished. The punctures subdivides the boundary of into boundary arcs. We will consider disks with numbered boundary arcs where the numbers correspond to the parallel copies . We will consider two types of numberings INCREASING and DECREASING: traversing the boundary of the disk in the positive direction starting from the distinguished puncture, the numbering increases or remain constant respectively decreases or remain constant as we pass the other punctures. We call punctures where the numbering changes non-constant and punctures where it does not change constant. If the boundary numbering has no constant puncture then we call it strictly increasing or strictly decreasing. We next consider asymptotic conditions at the boundary punctures. There are two basic forms of asymptotics, a puncture is either asymptotic to a Lagrangian intersection point or to a Reeb chord. The former case is the standard form of asymptotics on Lagrangian Floer theory and the latter in Legendrian DG-algebras. More precisely, we choose an almost complex structure on which in the cylindrical end is invariant under -translation, leaves the contact planes invariant and is compatible with the symplectic form induced on the contact planes by the contact form. Furthermore, it pairs the -direction with the Reeb direction. This means in particular that the Reeb chord strip which is the product of a Reeb chord and is holomorphic and we study holomorphic disks with boundary punctures that are asymptotic to these Reeb chord solutions. Consider a disk as above with strictly increasing or decreasing numbering and let be a word of Reeb chords and Lagrangian intersection points in . We let denote the moduli space of holomorphic disks that satisfies the following conditions: takes the boundary component labeled by to the Lagrangian . is asymptotic to the unique Reeb chord or Lagrangian intersection point of and near at , where we let . We next consider disks in the symplectization. Consider again the disk with boundary numbering and punctures . We next note that in the symplectization there are two possible Reeb chord asymptotics, positive or negative according to the sign of the -coordinate near the puncture. Let be a word of signed Reeb chords of , where is a sign. If then we require that the Reeb chords at all constant punctures connect to and that their signs are all negative, . We let denote the moduli space of holomorphic disks that satisfy the following conditions: takes the boundary components labeled by to the Lagrangian . is asymptotic at positive or negative infinity according to the sign of to the unique Reeb chord between and near at a puncture . We write for the moduli space of holomorphic disks satisfying these conditions. Finally, we consider disks in the cobordism and in the filled cobordism. We start with the cobordism disks without filling. Consider a system of parallel copies . Consider the disk where we fix two punctures that subdivide the boundary of the disk into two arcs, upper and lower. Let be a decreasing boundary numbering of the boundary components in the upper arc and extend it to a constant numbering in the lower arc. Let be a composable word of Reeb chords connecting to , and let be a word of Reeb chords of . Consider the word of Reeb chords and intersection points and let denote the moduli space of holomorphic disks such that the following holds. is asymptotic to the Reeb chord at its constant puncture, takes adjacent boundary arcs to , and neighboring punctures to the unique intersection point near in and near in , respectively. On remaining boundary arcs and punctures the boundary maps as described by and the numbering , exactly as above. The disks in the filled cobordism are entirely analogous. Here we assume that is a Lagrangian submanifold in . Consider again a system of parallel copies and also a system of parallel copies of . Consider the disk where we fix two punctures that subdivide the boundary of the disk into two arcs, upper and lower. Let be a decreasing boundary numbering of the boundary components in the upper and lower arcs. Let be a word of intersection points of and let be a word of Reeb chords of . Consider the word of Reeb chords and intersection points and let denote the moduli space of holomorphic disks such that the following holds. is asymptotic to the Reeb chord at its puncture in the lower arc, takes adjacent boundary arcs to , and neighboring punctures to the unique intersection point near in and the unique intersection point near in . On remaining boundary arcs and punctures the boundary maps as described by and the numbering , exactly as above. The formal dimension of the moduli spaces above is computed in terms of the negative of a Conley-Zehnder index of the Reeb chords. Recall of a Reeb chord of as defined for example in : we pick paths connecting base points in the boundary of the various components of , and paths connecting Reeb chord endpoints to the base points. We define to be the Maslov index of this path closed up by a positive rotation in the contact plane, and the grading . For a Lagrangian intersection between and we similarly pick paths connecting to the base points and use these to form a loop starting in and ending in and define to be the Maslov index of the loop of Lagrangian planes that results from closing up the path of Lagrangian planes along by a positive rotation, and . The above gradings are related to the grading in the Legendrian contact homology algebra, see e.g. as follows: The formal dimension of the moduli space equals The formal dimension of the moduli space equals The formal dimension of the moduli space equals The formal dimension of the moduli space equals See . We next study topological properties of the moduli spaces just defined. It turns out to be comparatively simple because of two key features. First, since we require our disks to switch copies at punctures “in the same direction” they cannot be multiply covered, and second, for the same reason there can be no boundary splitting. As in , the first property allows us to prove transversality by perturbing the almost complex structure and the second shows that the moduli spaces admit compactifications consisting only of punctured curves joined at Reeb chords. Precise formulations of these results are as follows. For generic almost complex structure the moduli spaces , , , and are transversely cut out manifolds of dimensions and , , and , respectively. To see this we note first that if is a disk in one of the moduli spaces then it cannot be multiply covered. We use the argument of . Fix a puncture of . Consider first the more difficult case when this puncture maps to a Lagrangian intersection. Pick coordinates so that the intersection point lies at the origin in and so that the two Lagrangians correspond to and . Let be standard coordinates on . Consider the complex hyperplanes . Looking at the Fourier expansion of near the puncture it is clear that for suitable coordinates (such that the leading Fourier coefficient of lies in direction of the first coordinate) the number of intersection points of the image of and near the puncture have different parities depending on the sign of . By analytic continuation, other disks and half disks mapping there either have images agreeing completely in the ball or there are injective points of the disk near the puncture. In the case where they agree completely we note that the parity of the number of intersection points in each local sheet not containing the puncture with is independent of sign. We the find that we can achieve transversality by perturbing the complex structure near : because the sheet with the puncture intersects only one of , if the contributions of the sheets mapping to cancel then those mapping to cannot cancel and vice versa, by unique continuation. The moduli space admits a compactification consisting of several level disks joined at Reeb chords and intersection points, where some levels may lie in the symplectization. The moduli space admits a compactification consisting of several level disks joined at Reeb chords. The moduli space admits a compactification consisting of several level disks joined at Reeb chords. There is one level of disks in the cobordisms and remaining levels in the symplectization ends. The moduli space admits a compactification consisting of several level disks joined at Reeb chords and intersection points. Note that the boundary condition on our punctured disks have the following property: any arc that subdivides the source into two components with a positive puncture in each must connect boundary components numbered with distinct numbers. This shows that there can be no boundary splitting. The theorem then follows from SFT compactness . We next discuss orientations of moduli spaces following . We fix capping operators at all Reeb chords and Lagrangian intersection points so that the two capping operators there glue to a disk with the Fukaya orientation, see . Recall the relative spin structure on the Lagrangian submanifold induces an orientation on the determinant bundle over the space of disks with boundary condition in the Lagrangian, see. As in we see that these choices then induces a system of coherent orientations on the moduli spaces. We will use one more property of the moduli spaces which says that they are effectively independent of the increasing or decreasing boundary labeling . Let and be two increasing (decreasing) boundary numberings. Then there are canonical orientation preserving diffeomorphisms Let denote either one of the above moduli spaces. This moduli space is the transverse zero set of a Fredholm section in a Banach bundle. Changing the numbering from to corresponds to an arbitrarily small isotopy which induces an arbitrarily small deformation of the section. The theorem follows.

outline.text: Wrapped Floer cohomology and Legendrian surgery
outline._note: In this section we outline an argument that establishes the isomorphism between and where is the co-core disk of the surgery. Our proof is a generalization of the corresponding result under Lagrangian handle attachment exposed in . Since the description there is rather brief we discuss the basic steps also in the original case here. More precisely, we first define a version of wrapped Floer cohomology using only purely holomorphic disks and show that the resulting theory agrees with the usual version defined in terms of holomorphic disks with a Hamiltonian term. Second we discuss the surgery isomorphism in , and third we discuss how to generalize that argument to partially wrapped Floer cohomology calculations.

Let be a Weinstein manifold and be an exact Lagrangian. Fix a system of shifting Morse functions that are positive at infinity and let be the corresponding family of parallel Lagrangian submanifolds. Define to be the chain complex generated by Reeb chords of and intersection points . We define operations on using what we call PARTIAL HOLOMORPHIC BUILDINGS. We start in the simplest case when the output of is an intersection point . Consider generators and consider a disk with a decreasing boundary numbering , distinguished negative (output) puncture and remaining punctures positive (inputs). Let and . Define Here we use the temporary notion to denote the summand of the full operation that takes values in intersection points. We next turn to the more complicated definition of the part of the operation that takes values in Reeb chord generators and to this end we introduce the notion of a partial holomorphic building. The domain of partial holomorphic building is a possibly broken disk with decreasing boundary numbering . The partial holomorphic buildings we consider always have exactly one disk in the symplectization. We call it the primary disk of the building. We require that the distinguished puncture which is increasing is a negative puncture of this primary disk. If the distinguished puncture is the only negative puncture of the primary disk then the partial building consist only of its primary component. If on the other hand the primary disk has additional negative punctures then we require that at each additional puncture (which is decreasing or constant) is a disk in the cobordism with decreasing boundary condition is attached at its distinguished increasing or constant puncture to the additional negative puncture. We call these disks the secondary disks of the partial building. The resulting partial holomorphic building is then a disk with domain a broken , with distinguished puncture a negative puncture at a Reeb chord and with remaining punctures either Reeb chords or intersection points. See Figure . (2,3) to (0.5,0); (2.5,3) to (4,0); (2,0) to (2.5,0); (3,0) to (3.5,0); (1,0) to (1.5,0); (0.5,-0.2) to (0,-0.2); (-0.5,-0.2) to (-1,-0.2); (-1.5,-0.2) to (-2,-0.2); (5,-0.2) to (5.5,-0.2); (4,-0.2) to (4.5,-0.2); (1,-0.2) to (-2.5,-0.2); (3.5,-0.2) to (6,-0.2); (3,-0.2) to (6.5,-0.2); (2.5,-0.2) to (7,-0.2); (-2,-0.2) to (-2.5,-0.2); (-1,-0.2) to (-1.5,-0.2); (0,-0.2) to (-0.5,-0.2); (1,-0.2) to (0.5,-0.2); (1,0) to (0.5,0); (2,0) to (1.5,0); (3,0) to (2.5,0); (4,0) to (3.5,0); (3,-0.2) to (2.5,-0.2); (4,-0.2) to (3.5,-0.2); (5,-0.2) to (4.5,-0.2); (6,-0.2) to (5.5,-0.2); (7,-0.2) to (6.5,-0.2); (2.5,3) to (2,3); at (1.5,2.5) []{}; at (3,2.5) []{}; at (1.3, 0.4) []{}; at (2.3, 0.4) []{}; at (3.3, 0.4) []{}; at (4.3, -0.6) []{}; at (5.3, -0.6) []{}; at (6.1, -0.6) []{}; at (6.6, -0.6) []{}; at (7.2, -0.6) []{}; at (0.3, -0.6) []{}; at (-0.7, -0.6) []{}; at (-1.7, -0.6) []{}; at (-2.7, -0.6) []{}; At additional negative punctures there may be constant holomorphic disks with one positive puncture and boundary on are attached. These are the usual augmentation disks, or disks on used as anchoring disks, compare Section . We write the punctures of the partial holomorphic disk building as , where is the distinguished puncture. Write for the moduli space of partial holomorphic disk buildings with boundary condition on according to . Using this we define for generators the operation where the sum ranges over Reeb chords with grading as indicated. Finally we define the total operation as the sum The -relations hold for the operations . First, Theorem shows that the operations compose and that they are independent of the choice of decreasing boundary numbering. To see that the relations hold we will as usual identify the terms contributing to them with the boundary of an oriented 1-dimensional compact manifold. To this end we first consider 1-dimensional moduli spaces of the form , where the distinguished puncture is an intersection point. As usual, the boundary numbering precludes boundary bubbling and we find that the boundary consists of broken disk that either break at an intersection point in which case the holomorphic parts both have dimension zero, or break into a partial holomorphic building with a rigid disk attached at its negative puncture, in which case the primary component of the partial building has dimension one. We find the boundary points of are in 1-1 correspondence with disks contributing to compositions of and (disks breaking at intersection points) and disks contributing to and . Remaining contributions to the -relations correspond to compositions of and . We identify also these with the boundary of an oriented 1-manifold. To this end we consider the boundary of the moduli space of dimension two with distinguished negative puncture. (After we divide out the natural -action this is 1-dimensional space.) The boundary consists of two level broken disks and completing all negative punctures except the distinguished puncture with rigid disks in we find also the composition of and expressed as the boundary of an oriented compact 1-manifold. The lemma follows.

We next show that the above definition of wrapped Floer cohomology agrees with the standard theory. We keep the geometric setting as above and write for the usual version of Hamiltonian wrapped Floer cohomology. A well known argument shows that that with differential is quasi-isomorphic to the wrapped Floer cohomology by a geometrically defined chain map. We extend this chain map to an -map which then a standard spectral sequence argument establishes the desired isomorphism. We follow the approach in where similar isomorphisms between contact and symplectic differential graded algebras were constructed. More precisely, as there we construct a splitting compatible non-negative field of -forms with values in Hamiltonian vector fields, and further a -parameter family of such forms interpolating between the zero Hamiltonian at the positive end and the Hamiltonian used to define wrapped Floer cohomology at the negative end, see . We then define the corresponding moduli spaces over the deformation interval. Keeping the notation from we denote them In order for the asymptotics at infinity of these maps to make sense we need to include the parallel copies of the Lagrangians according to boundary numbering, and in particular also to incorporate this in the description of wrapped Floer cohomology. More precisely, as in the case above we will have moduli spaces of Floer holomorphic disks with boundary in distinct Lagrangians that are arbitrarily close. The analogue of Theorem holds by the same argument and the corresponding moduli spaces are canonically isomorphic for sufficiently small perturbations. Using these observations we then define by The map is an homomorphism. To see this we note again that the disks which contributes to the relations correspond exactly to the ends of 1-dimensional moduli space. The map is a quasi-isomorphism. The map respects the word length filtration and is the standard isomorphism from the linearized Legendrian cohomology to the wrapped Floer cohomology on the -page.

outline.text: Wrapped Floer cohomology and Lagrangian handle attachment
outline._note: In this subsection we discuss the result in which gives a Legendrian surgery description of the wrapped Floer cohomology of a co-core disk in a Weinstein manifold obtained by Lagrangian handle attachment along a Legendrian sphere. To state this result we first introduce notation. Let be a Weinstein -manifold with ideal boundary the contact -manifold . Let be a Legendrian submanifold such that all of its components are parameterized -spheres. Let be the Weinstein manifold that results from attaching Lagrangian handles to . Here , where each component is a disk sub-bundle of the cotangent bundle of the -disk , and where is attached to . Then contains co-core disks corresponding to the cotangent fibers at the center of the disk in each . We let denote co-core disk in , denote its Legendrian boundary inside the contact boundary of , and write . As a first step in the calculation of the wrapped Floer cohomology of we describe the generators of the underlying chain complex. By the results in Section , generators of are of two kinds Lagrangian intersection points and Reeb chords. Here the Lagrangian intersection points are easily understood: pick the shifting Morse function so that it has one minimum on each component of and no other critical points, then there is exactly one intersection point for each component of . We denote the intersection point of by and we denote the subcomplex generated by the by . Remaining generators are Reeb chords of we write for the quotient complex and note that is generated by Reeb chords. Consider the link and let all components be decorated by minus, . Consider as a chain complex, generated by composable words of Reeb chords with differential and with product given by concatenation if the words are composable and zero otherwise. Let denote the size of the attaching region (i.e., the size of the tubular neighborhood of where is attached), we then have the following. For any there exists such that if then there is a natural one to one correspondence between the generators of of action and the generators of of action . [**Sketch of proof:**]{} It is clear that a Reeb chord connecting to converges to a composable word of Reeb chords, as . To construct a unique chord for each composable word for small handles of size one uses an explicit model of the handle centered around the origin in standard symplectic -space where the Reeb flow corresponds to the solution of a linear differential equation in combination with an elementary finite dimensional fixed point theorem. Details will appear in . We will next define the surgery map which is an -morphism that counts certain holomorphic disks. See Figure . Let be a composable word of Reeb chords connecting to , and let be a word of generators of . Consider the word of Reeb chords and intersection points Define , Note that if is the minimum of the Morse function on as above then because of the unique holomorphic disk corresponding to the flow line from the minimum to the intersection point between , for the parallel copies this gives a triangle with corners at , at , and at , and since there are no negative punctures the output is . Also, and if a word of generators of contains a generator and has length then as this corresponds to a holomorphic disk with a flow line from the minimum attached and such a configuration cannot be rigid unless the disk is constant. The maps gives an -map which is an quasi-isomorphism. [**Sketch of proof:**]{} In order to see the -relations we study the boundary of the moduli space . As usual the boundary numbering guarantees that there is no boundary splitting on . The boundary of the moduli space thus consists of the following configurations. Two level curves with one level in the cobordism and one in either symplectization end. Curves which split at the intersection point . Splitting corresponds to the map followed by the operation in . Splitting corresponds to the tensor product of the map followed by the product operation in . The -relations follow. To see that is a quasi-isomorphism we show that induces an isomorphism on homology by constructing algebraically one holomorphic disks interpolating between a Reeb chord of and the corresponding word of Reeb chords of . The existence of such disks implies that the map has a triangular matrix with respect to the action filtration and hence is a chain isomorphism, compare . To construct the required interpolating disks one starts from unique and uniformly transversely cut out such disks for single chord words obtained by a straightforward explicit geometric construction. Gluing such disks at their Lagrangian intersection punctures in and using small action to rule out all breakings except one, we find that there is algebraically one disk interpolating between a chord on and the corresponding word of chords of , see . The map being an -quasi-isomorphism then follows from the word length spectral sequence. A complete proof of Theorem has not yet appeared. In cases when splitting at Reeb orbits can be neglected it is possible to fill in the details in the above outline with classical techniques. As mentioned above, in the general case one must employ abstract perturbations to control holomorphic planes of anchored disks. The details of the perturbation scheme will not affect the argument. There is also an “upside-down” perspective on the surgery just described. Namely, one can start from the contact manifold and produce the contact manifold by doing so called -surgery on . In complete analogy with the above one shows that Reeb chords on are in natural one to one correspondence with words of Reeb chords on and one can construct an upside down surgery map of co-algebras: A similar argument also shows that this map is a quasi-isomorphism. Alternatively, one can prove this from the original surgery map using only algebra as follows. First write then since is co-nilpotent, see Section .

In this section we outline a surgery approach to the computation of wrapped Floer homology in a Weinstein manifold with wrapping stopped by a Legendrian in its boundary. We will use the following model for the ambient manifold. Fix a tubular neighborhood of in the contact boundary of and attach a disk-bundle neighborhood of the -section in along the boundary just like in Lagrangian handle attachment. We use a Liouville vector field on this domain that agrees with the standard Liouville vector field pointing outwards along fibers in the cotangent bundle over for some . Let the components of be denoted , . Fix a base point for each . Let denote the cotangent fiber . We will compute the wrapped Floer cohomology of for sufficiently large using a surgery approach. We first consider the surgery map into the Chekanov-Eliashberg algebra with loop space coefficients. Consider all components of decorated by a positive sign and consider which now involves, except for Reeb chords, also chains on the based loop space. We define an - map where -structure on the left hand side is the standard DG-algebra structure induced by concatenation and the Pontryagin product. As in Section , consider a disk with two dividing punctures that subdivides the boundary into two arcs, lower and upper. Let the upper arc contain boundary punctures and is equipped with a decreasing boundary numbering and the lower arc boundary punctures. Let be Reeb chords of and let be Reeb chords of . Let and consider , again as in Figure . Theorems and show that this moduli space carries a fundamental chain. We view this chain as parametrizing chains of paths in connecting the Reeb chord endpoints in . We write for the alternating word of chains of loops and Reeb chords and view it as an element in . Define the maps as The map is an -map. To see that the -relation holds we look at the boundary of the moduli space of dimension . The codimension one boundary consists of three splittings: A one-dimensional curve splits off in the positive symplectization end. A one-dimensional curve splits off at the negative end. Splitting at one of the intersection points . In order for splittings of the form to contribute to the codimension one boundary of the moduli space the part of the holomorphic building in consists of rigid disks with only positive punctures attached at one puncture to a negative puncture of the disk in the positive end and a disk of dimension in attached at the remaining negative puncture. Assembling the rigid disks and the one-dimensional disk we get a partial holomorphic disk building that contributes to the -operations in followed by the map . Splittings of type corresponds to the map followed by the differential in . Finally splittings of type correspond to the map followed by the product on . We conclude that the terms contributing to -relations express the codimension one boundary of in two different ways and hence is an -map. We will use slight generalizations of the map below. More precisely, if , are points in and if is the cotangent fiber at then we have a similar surgery map which counts holomorphic disks with a positive Reeb chord connecting to , two Lagrangian intersection punctures at and at , and a word of chains of loops in and Reeb chords of as output, and where is directly analogous to but where the first chain of loops is in a word is replaced by a chain of paths from to the base point and the last is replaced by a chain of paths from the base point to . In this setup the counterpart of the second component is and counts disks with two positive punctures at Reeb chords and two Lagrangian intersection punctures at and . The counterpart of the -equations in this setup is then where is the differential on and where is the (Pontryagin) product . The proofs of these statements are word by word repetitions of the proof of Theorem . We next sketch a proof that the map in Theorem is in fact a quasi-isomorphism, or, in other words, that its first component induces an isomorphism on homology. We filter by action of its Reeb chord generators. To get a corresponding filtration on we use action on Reeb chords in combination with the energy on the loops. We start with a discussion of the energy of loops, following . Equip with a Riemannian metric and denote the space of based loops in with the supremum norm: for two loops , where is the metric on induced by the Riemannian structure. Then the metric topology on agrees with the standard compact open topology. Let denote the space of piecewise smooth paths with metric where denotes the derivative of . The natural inclusion is a homotopy equivalence, . We will use finite dimensional approximations to study . The energy of a piece-wise smooth loop in is For , let denote the subset of loops of energy . The space can be approximated by piece-wise geodesic loops. More precisely, fixing a subdivision of we consider the space of loops of energy that are geodesic on each interval . Then shows that for all sufficiently fine subdivisions is a finite dimensional manifold (a submanifold of the product in a natural way). Moreover , all critical points of lie in which is a deformation retract of and for generic metric is a Morse function. With these preliminaries established we turn to the actual proof. The first step will be to describe the Reeb chords of . Let be a Riemannian metric on as above and let be a positive function with , , and monotone increasing. Define the metric on by Then if and are points in and is a geodesic with and then there is a unique geodesic such that and ; is Morse with has a unique maximum at an interior point . Note that the Reeb flow in the unit disk bundle is the natural lift of the geodesic flow. Assume next as above that the metric on is generic in the sense that the length functional for curves connecting any two Reeb chord endpoints in has only Morse critical points. Concretely, this means that the index form of any geodesic connecting two Reeb chord endpoints is non-degenerate. As in Lemma , this allows us to control the Reeb chords of below a given action for all sufficiently thin handles. More precisely, let denote the size of the tubular neighborhood of in where we attach and we introduce the following notion of a geodesic-Reeb chord word. A GEODESIC-REEB CHORD WORD is a word where is a geodesic from one of the base points to the start point of the Reeb chord , where is a geodesic from the endpoint of to the start point of , etc, until finally is a geodesic from the endpoint of the Reeb chord to one of the base points . We define the action of a geodesic-Reeb chord word to be the sum of actions of its Reeb chords and the energies of its geodesics. For any there exists and such that for any and any there is a natural one to one correspondence between Reeb chords of of action and geodesic-Reeb chord words of of action . [**Sketch of proof:**]{} The proof uses the transversality of the Reeb chords and of the geodesics. The basic observation is that the point in the normal fiber of where the Reeb flow hits determines the direction of the geodesic in . After introducing a concrete smoothing of corners the lemma then follows from the finite dimensional inverse function theorem. To show that is a quasi-isomorphism we will show that it is represented by a triangular matrix with ones on the diagonal with respect to the action/energy filtration. To this end we will use the Morse theoretic finite dimensional model for the chain complex underlying the homology of the based loop space described above. In order to have defined as a chain in this model we need to assure that the paths on the boundary of the holomorphic disk are sufficiently well behaved. We only sketch the construction. On holomorphic disk with unstable domains, we fix gauge using small spheres surrounding Reeb chord endpoint, compare . As in we use a configuration space for holomorphic curves consisting of maps with two derivatives in . This means that the restriction to the boundary has derivatives in and in particular the projection to has bounded energy. Since the action of the positive puncture in a holomorphic disk contributing to the differential controls the norm of the solution it follows that we can use configuration spaces of bounded energy to study the disks in the differential: we approximate the boundary curves uniformly by a piecewise geodesic curve by introducing a uniformly bounded number of subdivision points and straight line homotopies in small charts. The chain-map induces an isomorphism on homology. [**Sketch of proof:**]{} Consider a word of the form where are geodesics in and where are Reeb chords. We aim to construct algebraically one disk connecting the Reeb chord of , corresponding to this word (see Lemma ), to the word itself. We use an inductive argument and energy filtration. To start the argument we pick additional fiber disks and in at and for very small near all Reeb chord end points and in . We use the natural counterparts of the for mixed wrapped Floer homologies. For example, there is a straightforward analogue of Lemma : Reeb chord generators of correspond before the surgery words of the form where is a geodesic connecting the base point of to the startpoint of , from the endpoint of to the start point of , etc. To start the argument we note that it is straightforward to construct holomorphic strips corresponding to the short geodesics starting at followed by the chord and then the short geodesic to and to show that they are unique. This corresponds to a generator of . Likewise, it is immediate to construct the holomorphic disk connecting a Reeb chord generator of corresponding to a geodesic, and show that it is unique, compare Lemma . We now use these two to construct algebraically one disk from the Reeb chord generator of corresponding to the short geodesic, the chord , and a geodesic connecting the endpoint of to the base point of . To this end we consider the natural map see . For the two Reeb chords connecting to corresponding to the chord of , and connecting to corresponding to the geodesic we then have (with denoting the base point): Here we know that the terms containing and involves non-trivial holomorphic disks or Morse flows in the finite dimensional approximation and hence lowers action/energy by an amount bounded below by some which we assume is much larger than above. Therefore, if we restrict attention to a small action window we find Here the first term is simply the Pontryagin product at the common endpoint of the curves, which is homologous to the word of the small geodesic, the Reeb chord and then the longer geodesic, by rounding the corner at . It follows that , where is a Reeb chord with action between the sum of the actions of and and the action of and that contains this word with coefficient . Noting that there is only one Reeb chord in the action window studied we find that the desired coefficient equals . It is now clear how to continue the induction, in each step we add one more geodesic or Reeb chord to any word. Using already constructed curves and in a small action window we find that the map has a triangular action matrix with on the diagonal, hence it is a quasi-isomorphism.
